Sherri Q here. I started out studying music in college, but got married before I finished school. I ended up a year later going back to school...this time to a technical institute called ITT. I went to study Computer-Aided Drafting and Design.

The computer program of use was AutoCad. We learned how to use the program for Mechanical, Civil, Architectual, and Electrical drafting.

Originally I had thought I wanted to do Architectual, but soon found out I didn't like it. I preferred Mechanical or Civil.

I now work in the Civil Engineering field as a Engineering Technician (CAD Drafter is what it is often called).

I have worked in private companies, with strict deadlines and having to account for every second of time...thankfully I now work for the City.

Here at the City, things are relaxed and deadlines are approximate (for the most part). My job involves using AutoCad to draw out construction plans for sidewalks, streets and underground pipes for water and wastewater.

I also use ArcView GIS to draw exhibits for City Council meetings or other meetings, or to just gather needed information. GIS is a Geographical program. I use the bare bones of it in my profession.

My job is not stressful at all...not working for the City, at least. The Engineers I work with (yes, you work directly with Engineers) are all nice...quirkly but nice!

In the private sector I had to deal with a lot of crap. Pushy, demanding Engineers who had no concept of how long it would take to do a job, always wanting it "yesterday." If something wasn't right, they'd often lay into you, even if it wasn't your fault. Deadlines were very strict (sometimes unreasonable) and overtime was common when on a tight deadline.

Overtime is unheard of here at the City. 5:01pm and it's a ghost town.

This occupation is not as artistic as it may seem. Civil Engineering doesn't allow a lot of room for creativity. It's more techincal and mathematical, therefore for the creative mind can get highly monotinous.

This occupation is great for analytical minds. Close attention to detail is needed. Being able to communicate well is essential, because frankly, many engineers are so technically minded they don't communicate well. Sometimes you have to be a mind reader. You have to have a good sense of balancing your time and meeting deadlines.

I'm not good at math, but it certainley helps to be in this profession. But, I get along fine (caresses calculator). I've had to use elements of Geometry and Trigonometry and yes, even Algebra...thankfully not too much. Mostly though, the Engineers do all the math. As long as you type in the right numbers into the computer, you should be fine!

The best part of my job is that I don't often have to go outside (it's hot here in Texas).

The worst part of my job is that it gets old after a while. Monotonous.

1111111211.content:
A DAY IN THE LIFE OF A FUND DEVELOPMENT OFFICER

I was the first college graduate in all the generations of my families who came from Europe three and five generations earlier. It was a proud moment for me the first day I attended classes in college September of 1956 after graduating from Modesto High School.

College graduation at Fresno State College that June 1960 was a beautiful Sunday afternoon and I proudly accepted my Bachelor's Degree which prepared me for teaching English, Writing, History and Social Studies. Those were my favorite high school courses so I thought it would be great to teach those subjects to high school and junior high students.

The contract I signed with Ceres, California School District said that all of my classes but one would be eighth grade Creative Writing and one seventh grade math class. I developed the curriculum for Creative Writing and during the year and my students produced some wonderful poems and essays. I loved teaching the classes and watching the least capable among them become creative writers. I still have some of their writings which I read again recently. To this day, I think the District should never have employed a math teacher who had not studied how to teach math. While I did my best to teach my math students, I have always thought they were cheated by the District for requiring a non-math teacher to hold them hostage an hour a day. The students deserved a teacher trained in the art of teaching math, not a teacher who knew her math very well but had no training in teaching it.

After teaching for several years, I changed vocations and became the Volunteer Director at the Idaho State School and Hospital for the intellectually disabled. That was 1969 and I quickly fell in love with the accomplishments that I could cause by doing the statewide job I had accepted. One goal was to teach people all over the state to stop using words like 'idiot, imbecile, moron, mongoloid and worse' names. At that time, the words 'mentally retarded' was the most respectable term we wanted people to use. At the same time, the job included recruiting and training ordinary people and students of all ages to visit the institutional home of over four hundred individuals and make personal contributions to their lives. It didn't take long for me to fall in love with that job and the wonderful volunteers who gave of themselves to help individuals who just wanted a friend. I worked with women who were community leaders to raise funds and build the All Faiths Chapel at the in
stitution which today, years later, serves less than two hundred residents and patients, most of whom can't understand religion; but, I believe they know God.

Those experiences and others led me to accept the position of Development Director, a fund raiser, to raise money for hospitals and other nonprofit activities. My years of fund development led to raising over six million dollars for my organizations. I developed the Fund Development Program at Mercy Medical Center, Nampa, Idaho, by making speeches to all community groups in the area while designing and implementing a Direct Mail program for sending those 'infernal' letters asking for donations that every resident in America receives from charitable organizations. It takes a heart and skill to write those letters in a way that leads thousands of people to write checks and give their money for the benefit of someone else.

Development Directors like me, learn how to plan and implement fund raising events and activities that are so much fun that people give money to the charity. The primary part of such events was the recruitment of community leaders and other talented and interested people to serve on the planning committee. For the Annual Tennis Tournament which lasted more than ten years, I recruited five tennis players who served as the planning committee all of those years. They included an insurance agent, an intensive care nurse, a school librarian, a cardiologist and a banker. My job was to guide and serve them and 'pick up the pieces', the tasks that made their work successful. I also created an annual Golf Tournament that still continues to be one of the best in the state. For another hospital where I was Foundation Fund Development Director, I created the Festival of Trees which raised twenty-eight thousand dollars the first year and over a hundred thousand its fifth year. Aga
in, the creation and serving of a community committee was the basis of the success. An Annual Gin Rummy Tournament was a huge success at one medical center.

Fund Development Directors must find ways to develop long term donors. With that focus, I met with individuals, wrote letters, promoted the charity through a newsletter, produced brochures and designed donor recognition methods. Each day, I made personal or mailing contacts to donors and potential donors who were individuals, business leaders, ordinary individuals and a variety of organizations.

Researching sources of major funding was always important in my work of raising money for charitable organizations. Not only did I learn how to and successfully wrote grant proposals that were funded by Foundations, Corporations, state and federal government, but I developed training programs on the "how to" of fundraising and grant writing so that others could learn. Even though they competed with me in fundraising and writing grant proposals, there was always money for all of us if we wrote quality grant requests. I became called "the Dean of Fundraising" in Idaho during those years because I shared my knowledge and success with others.

On an ordinary day in life as a Fund Development Director, I would meet with one or more staff members, meet with the Board of Directors or the Management Team, write 'thank you' letters, make telephone calls and keep appointments, edit and publish newsletters, write grant proposals to Foundations and Corporations or government sources, meet with volunteers to plan events, oversee office activities and supervise staff, while always focusing on progress and growth for creating new ways to raise money for the clients of the charitable organization.

Looking back, besides raising those six million dollars, I set into play hundreds of activities and recruited hundreds of volunteers and donors to continue the work after I left so I choose to take credit for the fundraising work that transpired for the benefit of the deserving clients of each organization even after I moved on and retired. I am proud of every volunteer I recruited, every grant proposal I wrote, every dollar raised and every friend gained for the organizations and their clientele whom I served 1969 to 1999.

The work was a challenge and I am blessed.

I teach high school English. This is a job in which there is a great amount of preparation, such as writing lesson plans, reading all assigned reading for students, and gathering materials for each lesson. All assignments that students complete, whether in class or homework, must be graded as promptly as possible so that students receive feedback. Teachers must also plan for discipline issues--you should know what to do if and when a student misbehaves or disrupts class, as any disruptions interfere with student learning. Sometimes there are students with special needs, so the teacher must keep an eye out for these students especially, though all students need to be observed for understanding of the lesson.

A typical day is packed full of five classes, which is a normal teaching load, and any other duties that may be assigned. Teachers are often assigned duties such as monitoring a study hall, lunch duty, hall duty, etc. in addition to teaching. Teachers are supposed to have one period for planning, in which no other duties would be assigned, though occasionally there is an emergency need for a teacher to substitute for another teacher if there is no other sub available.

I arrive at work a half hour before school begins, and I set up my room for the day by writing information or objectives for the day on the board, making sure I have all materials, copies of assignment sheets, etc., whatever is needed for the day. I have my list of students and seating chart for each class on my podium so that I can check attendance quickly at the beginning of class.

When class begins, I am responsible for taking accurate attendance within the first five minutes of the period. My school uses a computer program to submit attendance, so I check the seating chart right when the bell rings, and it is essential that all students are in their seats. Students not in their seats are tardy, if they show up to class at all. I usually have bell work, a short assignment, ready for students to complete, while I go to my computer, enter attendance, and submit it. Any students wandering in late must bring a tardy slip to hand to me. If not, they are sent out to get one. This is so the main office has a record of their tardiness--otherwise I have to keep changing the attendance on the computer, which I do not have time for. Then, we briefly check bell work, and then the lesson starts. I sometimes lecture briefly, assign a group or pair activity, or we discuss the reading students had to do, or check homework--and at the end of the period I assign homework if necessary. Then, the bell rings and students leave. I go out into the hall and watch students pass from one class to the next to be sure that everyone is safe. The next class students arrive and enter the room. The bell rings, and I do everything all over again.

The planning and grading are time consuming, and I work continuously all day, and then I work more in the evening after work to finish grading or plan for the next day. I also work all weekend on grading and planning typically. This is a never-ending job, and I always have to take work home with me. There is little time to spend on other things, such as spending time with my family.

To be a successful teacher, you must love doing the job, and you must be willing to give everything to it.
11111211.title: High School English Teacher

The gap year is an interesting thing - it sort of puts you in limbo between high school and college. On one hand, you can't call yourself a high school student anymore since you've already graduated; on the other hand, you can't call yourself a college student since you've never attended. But there are huge advantages to a gap year if it is spent wisely, particularly in my case.

My story is rather uncommon. Due to skipping a grade in elementary school, I finished high school at the age of 16. I also landed an acceptance at UC Berkeley. But due to various reasons, including some that were health-related, my parents decided against sending me off to college at such a young age and instead allowed me to take a year off.

My year so far has been great - it's consisted of international travel, lots of writing, and re-applying to colleges. In August, my father and I went on the longest trip of our lives so far as we traveled around the Mediterranean on a cruise and visited Switzerland and Austria. In September, I accompanied him to North Korea, as we were invited by one of his friends. This particular friend owned a company that was in a joint venture with a North Korean company, and we had been invited for the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the joint venture. Normally trips into North Korea can only be possible for business or diplomatic reasons, although the government is also starting to sponsor limited tours. Nevertheless, the country remains one of the least visited, yet most intriguing, places on earth. The most memorable part of our trip was when we visited the 38th Parallel between both Koreas. It was incredible to see that soldiers from two countries, which had shared the same geographic peninsula, language, culture, and blood ties for thousands of years, were now facing each other in nothing but hatred.

It's only been the beginning, but I can tell that this year will have many more memorable adventures to come. Quite honestly, I couldn't have asked for a better year, and I don't regret my decision at all.

Blake obediently drops the chicken in the appropriate containers. Let me explain the lingo above. The first number signifies the number of baskets present to be filled with chicken, while the second determines the number of snacks.           Propping my sunglasses on top of my head, I enter through the automatic doors. A cool blast of the air conditioning greets me as I enter. I have served as a church organist/choir director/head of music at my church for 6 years now. It's not exactly as easy as most people would think. The tasks I'm put to can be very random, and no day is ever the same.

Sherri Q here again...I got a chance to interview a Senior Code Enforcement Officer for the City that I work for. Thank you Rex for your time!

[Sherri] Describe a typical day...

[Rex] Typical Day: We work Mon-Fri 8-5, and since working here only have worked one Sat (in Feb) from 8-2pm on a special project: picking up all those stake signs on streets. What I like is you have a lot of independance from close supervision, if you do the work there is minimal oversight. I also like the fact that I am in the office for a hour or so in the a.m. then on the street til lunch, after lunch back at the office for a while then out again. We respond to calls from citizens about tall grass, brush piles and trash, also zoning violations ( home occupation violations, illegal setback of structures, large vehicles left on the street etc...all those miniscule muni code violations). Good communication skills is absolutely necessary. Most people who have a violation and get emotional about it, I am able to talk to and get them to see the big picture, why we are doing this and they will end up concuring.

[Sherri] What is the worst/most difficult problem you've encountered and was it solved?

[Rex] Most diff. prob: There really are no difficult problems, they all have logical solutions. Some take more time to deal with and require getting warrants to go onto land from judges, but that stuff isn't really difficult just time consuming. People skills is the most difficult... not blowing your cork when you might like to. Sometimes I have had to consciously remind myself not to spout off as much as you might like. I was a cop for 30 yrs so have lots of training in that. People will call us directly to complain that we are not acting fast enough, rarely do they make an official complaint and or go to city manager etc...

[Sherri] How much paperwork and phone work is involved?

[Rex] Lots of phone work, we have a decent soft ware program and it has minimal paper work. just fill in the blanks etc...

[Sherri] Do you just deal with residential properties, or does the job stretch into commercial as well?

[Rex] All property within the city limits, however zoned. We deal only with sign violations in our "extra territorial jurisdiction" which is land not in the city but sort of consigned to [the city] for probable later inclusion into the city.

[Sherri] Do you ever have to deal with construction codes, building codes, fire codes, etc., or is that a different position altogether?

[Rex] Very infrequently with construction codes (setback violations of decks or accessory buildings are most common)

[Sherri] What is the average pay scale/range for a Code Enforcement Officer-Trainee and also an Officer and is it hourly or salary (referring to the [city we work in])?

[Rex] I make something over $16 an hr.and that is mid - range in the pay steps. Was hired last Nov. after 1 1/2 yrs as a code ofcr in [another city] so they did not start me a entry level. Acutally we have three officers: Zoning officer, Code enforcement officer, and a senior code enforcement officer (me). I suppose all three have different pay levels but are probably pretty close to each other.

[Sherri] Obviously there's some amount of dealing with the public involved...would you say the public is generally cooperative or generally defiant, and how much time is used in speaking/communicating with them?

[Rex] Just an awful lot of phone calls and explaining to complainants and culprits what the process is, how long it takes and what happens if they don't comply. We get a high rate of compliance...if they fail to comply like cutting tall grass we have our sub contractor do it and they end up paying the actual cutting cost plus a $120 administrative fee, if they dont pay we lien their property, so as you can expect most people comply... Hope this helped.

[Sherri] Yes it did, Rex! Thank you so much for your time!

I am a CNA (Certified Nursing Aide). My workday starts with a report on all of my patients. Vitals are taken every four hours (during a 12 hour work day). Patients are assisted in bathing, ambulating, and ADLs (activities of daily living). I assist patients to get up to chairs for meals. Some patients require special attention: turning every two hours; changing briefs; feeding; etc.

CNAs also help patients by meeting emotional needs. Hospital stays can be traumatic. CNAs can be "sympathetic ears" for their patients and patient family members. I help patients to meet their goals (i.e. leaving the hospital to go home, getting up out of bed, walking all of the way down the hall, etc.).

CNAs assist other medical staff such as nurses, respiratory therapists, physical and occupational therapists, dieticians, physicians, and transporters. Because CNAs tend to see a patient more often than other staff, we can provide valuable information regarding a patient. I tend to have the same set of patients for several days (sometimes months). I can immediately notice changes in vitals, awareness, physical ability, eating habits, and emotional states. Hospital staff depend on me to alert them to potential problems with patients.

I am also trained to perform EKGs, to work as a sitter when required, and to use various equipment. One-on-one sitters are usually warranted when a patient is confused to the point of possibly self-endangerment. Sometimes a patient will be admitted on a Legal Hold (which may be that the patient has suicidal ideations). I am also required to provide assistance during a Code Blue.

The best case scenario has me working with 6-9 patients. Many days I will work with up to 12 patients. I work on a post-operative floor, which means that I am constantly helping prep patients for surgery, receiving post-operative patients, and discharging patients. The job requires me to adjust to constant changes.

My particular job allows me 3-15 minute breaks and 1-30 minute breaks. In reality I usually get a quick break for breakfast (10 minutes) and a quick lunch break (20-30 minutes). I rarely sit down during the 12-hour shift.

My job requires me to lift and move very heavy patients and heavy equipment. I must have fantastic motivational skills (to get those patients up and moving). I also have to be able to work with different personality types. I need to remain calm during stressful events (codes, non-compliant patients, deaths). I have to take on difficult jobs with grace and compassion (comforting family members, cleaning dead bodies, etc.) Attention to detail is important. Little things mean a lot to someone confined to a hospital room/bed: blinds drawn properly; modesty protected; equipment in working order.

I have to be accurate in my charting of vitals and patient assessments. CNAs have to be cognizant of HIPAA. The State Health Department routinely visits the hospital and CNAs must following good practices. I am required by my state to hold an active CNA license and an active BLS certificate (CPR certification).

CNAs are the frontline in patient care. This job is very difficult but also very rewarding.

I am an Assitant Production Editor at a major textbook publishing house.

My daily routine consists of getting up and getting dressed for the office. You almost always have to dress professional for my job; occasionally we'll have "Denim Days" on Friday, but usually we have to look nice--business-like. It's only a 20 minute drive to my office from my apartment so I usually get there a little early to find a parking spot and get in a few good points with the boss, should she happen to call before I'm technically supposed to be there (it's happened before).

We all have ID cards which we have to use to get into the building--otherwise, the security guard gets irriated and we have to sign in while he frowns at us. Once safe in my cubicle I turn on my computer an look over my desk for the day's projects. A "project" is what we call a book. Just pick up a textbook and look at it--from cover to cover, that is what I help work on. We can have more than one project going at at once--in fact, a couple of weeks ago, I'm sure I looked at pages for books ranging from kindgergarten to sixth grade.

My routine can vary from day to day; it depends on what stage a project is on and whether or not it will need a production read. On a good, busy day, I'll have several units (from a book) to look over. It's a very complicated process at times, and though I've been at it nearly a year, I'm still learning things. It sometimes makes me feel stupid, but I remind myself that it's a complex business and not everyone can know everything--even though my boss does seem to at times.

At the beginning of a project, for example, like one I finished up a few weeks ago, we production editors will be called to do "cold reads" of parts of the manuscript. A lot of textbooks aren't created new--sometimes they're just released with updated text (such as election data and so forth), photos, and layouts. The project I started on was like that, but we had to do a cold read of the MS so we could see what needed correcting. A cold read is a basic editing runthrough: we check for grammar, punctuation, and anything that looks weird on the page (you wouldn't believe how many little things can go wrong after we send the MS out-of-house to be assembled). If I'm lucky, I get to mark directly on the page with a pen, if not, I'll have to go through scads of post-it notes to get my meaning across. Production eds can also rearrange text to for clarification or suggest additional words and sentences, but that's really a content editor's job. This process will go on for weeks. The MS doesn't just stay at my desk, but it gets passed around for other pairs of eyes to see what they can see--and also, my suggestions need approval by the executive editors of the projects. Sometimes changes can't be made because of deadlines that have to be met, othertimes, the change is so small and there's nothing else on the page, that we ignore it--sending out even one page costs money and there's a high chance that the vender (the people who assemble the pages from the files we send) will screw it up.

Sometimes, especially near the end of a poject when deadlines are looming (along with millions of dollars of profit on the line), work will be so busy that I have to stay over my usual 8-4. That really stinks because I don't get paid overtime, but it looks good to the boss, so it's better just to smile and keep working. You see, my job is contract, so I can definately be kicked out as soon as my contract ends--which happened before at a different branch at this same publishing house. So you need to prove that you're a useful, hard-working member of the team if you want to stay.

It's definately a harder job than I expected, but I really enjoy it at times. I was an English major so I'm happy to be doing something related to my chosen field. The people are all very nice and most of them fellow book nerds and word lovers.

If you want a job in editing, it's a good idea to network. Ask people where they work and if you know someone in publishing, milk that for all it's worth. I graduated with a girl who works at my publishing house--it's probably due to her recommendation that I got hired in the first place. Also, hone your editing skills. I recommend "Woe is I" by Patricia O'Connor and any other grammar book you can get your hands on.

Check up on the websites of major publishers too; most of them have job listings posted and places where you can apply online--that's how I got my job.

1233.content:
I love my job. After all, I'm in the right place for forgiveness if I muck up, and you can't get much higher up the career ladder than my boss.

I'm British, and work for a Church of England parish church in the Northern Province. I'm self-employed in the roll and work out of the Parish Hall, which is also a community centre. I love that, because it brings me into daily contact with a variety of local community groups and their members.

I work hours to suit (12 per week) and in that time I have to co-ordinate the schedule of bookings, billing, and upkeep of the hall, as well as fit in my regular Parish Administrator tasks:

Liturgy
We are a High Church of England church, and as such follow the Roman Missal and many traditions associated with catholic worship (we have Mass, not a service). The priest wears vestments and liturgical colours, and we use the Jerusalem Bible. My job is to follow the liturgy and create orders of service for Sundays, Saints' days and Holy days. I use the church calendar to base the liturgy on. So, mid-week is spent creating Sunday's order of service, with relevant readings to the liturgical calendar, appropriate hymns and responses. It is then mass produced for the congregation.

Weekly Notices
I create (via publisher) a weekly leaflet, which notes the Mass times, Mass intentions, Intercessions, key Parish Diary dates, and notices for the week. This is distributed on a Sunday to the congregation, sent out via email (we're a green parish), and uploaded as a PDF on the Parish website, which I also update.

Door Times
Ours is a busy and vibrant Parish, so each week I produce a list of events, activities, Mass Times and Mass Intentions which is used in poster form in both the Hall and the Church.

Weekly Readings
Readers need to know what they will be reading in advance, and Eucharistic Ministers need to be able to pass on the Sunday readings to the housebound. As part of the Order of Service, I create and produce a reading sheet with relevant prayers, readings, gospel acclamation, communion antiphon and dismissal blessing on it.

Intercessions
Prayer is a big part of any Parish's ministry and ours is no exception. I create a list of those in need of prayer: the sick, the recently departed, the anniversaries of the departed, marriages and baptisms.


As well as the weekly church items, there are a number of other administrative tasks, too:

The Parish Magazine
This is monthly and I collate articles, event notices, advertisements, Mass times and Intentions for the month ahead. I work alongside other Magazine contributors to print, staple and distribute the magazine.

Baptisms
Specific details and enquiries are taken by the Priest or the Church Wardens. I handle part of the administrative processing for baptisms, updating them in the Priest's and parish's diaries, sending letters, contacting the those who are needed for the event, eg., organist, verger, wardens etc.

Weddings
Initial contact, marriage preparation and Office Hour enquiries are taken on by the Priest. I handle part of the administrative processing for weddings, and deal with deposits and payments, updates in the Priest's and parish's diaries, sending letters, contacting the those who are needed for the event, eg., organist, verger, wardens etc. When the Priest is away I help ensure the relevant details are actioned (such as Banns etc.)

Funerals
Thankfully, the Parish Priest deals with families of the recently departed. My job is to help create and produce an order of service when there is a Requiem Mass; although, I do occasionally have to liaise with Funeral Directors, as well.

Admin
General office duties include reception, email, typing, filing, photocopying, etc.


I do think mine is the best job in the world. I feel my administrative support enhances the worship of the Parish, the work of the Parish Priest, and that of the Parochial Church Council. I also get to meet wonderful people, volunteers, and community groups who do so much good in the wider community outside of church.

12331.content:
"Let me know when you've got your coffee and are settled in".

I hate walking in to work in the morning to hear my staff spit out this sentence. It will never lead to "something great happened last night here at the house". Usually it will entail cleaning up the mess of an incompetent staff, explaining to a parent why I can't do the impossible for their loved one, filing a report with the state, or contacting the county regarding another person for which we are permanently revoking services.

Currently I am the Associate Director of Respite Services for an agency. We have 29 community homes that house permanent residents that are Mental Health, Mental Retardation, Physically disabled, or any combination of the above. The home I run has two permanent residents and two respite beds. The respite part of it you could liken to a hotel. They come and go. From one night to one month, and anywhere in between. This usually depends on an individuals funding and how many nights they are allotted. Most of the time families will call and schedule times for their loved one to stay so they can have a break. Other times the county calls with what they deem an emergency situation and do not care who is in that spot and bump them out for their supposed "emergency". Most of the parents are grateful for any time they get. Others feel the world owes them everything. Some parents understand their child/family member is not the only one residing at the house during their stay. Others expect me and my staff to ignore everyone else and take care of only their child.

When I was eighteen and graduating high school, I never thought I would end up here. I had no clue what I wanted to do with my life. My cousin had just finished getting a degree in Social Services and was running a group home nearby. Due to the fact it was a newly opened home, they were completely short staffed. She asked me to just come up and try it for a weekend. If I wanted a job that would be great. If not, no harm done and my crappy job at the grocery store would be waiting for me on Monday. When I walked into that group home on Friday evening, it changed me. Sitting there starting at me from the dinner table were six mentally and physically disabled adults. Some had the "oh goodie, someone else who will help me" look, while others had the "ahhh..fresh meat" look. Twenty-seven years later, I am still here. I am not at the same group home. I am not even with the same agency. I have however, run the gambit of positions within an agency. Everything from a residential worker, vocational worker, Supervisor of a day program classroom, to where I am today.

I've learned the bad along with the good. I've learned that the system isn't always fair and it isn't always who needs the services the most that gets them, versus the squeaky wheel gets the grease. In other words, who complains the loudest usually gets the services. I've learned that most Doctors, Dentists, Nurses, etc. would just prefer to pretend special needs individuals do not exist and will go out of their way to make your life miserable just so you will go to another practice. What they don't realize is that the individual's insurance dictates where they can go, and not many places take their insurance. I've learned that those who receive social security benefits are limited to how much money they can have in a savings account, so you will find yourself spending their money on things they don't need just so they won't lose their S.S. income, all at taxpayer expense. I've also learned I've become bitter because of the system. I've also been bitten, spit on, beaten up, and sent to the emergency room. I've called the police to have someone committed to the psyche ward because we can't control them and they are trying to chase us with a knife. I've learned you really DO need to have a heart of gold and really want to help people because the pay is crappy.

On the flip side, I've seen, and received, unconditional love. I've been hugged just for helping someone tie their own shoes. I've been asked about my vacation when no one else cared. I've felt that I honestly was missed over the weekend. I've seen the spark in the eye when the body traps them in a wheelchair. I've felt the joy when someone we were told would never speak, greets me at the door and says "hi". I've shed the tears while sitting next to someone's bed while they struggle to hold onto life. I've felt the pride when grown adults finally learns to feed themselves.

I've also had the moments when all is settled and I am sitting in my office reflecting on these moments and know I am where I am supposed to be.

All in all, I made the right choice at the time. You do have to love helping people because you will not become a millionaire working in this field. You have to be able to give, as well as receive, unconditional love. If you can do that, you've got it made.
12331.title: Associate Director of Respite Services

12332.content:
Ok, so I've had a fair number of jobs so far and disliked pretty much all of them. The job I have enjoyed the most is one I pretty much stumbled into. I live in a rural community and there are several schools in the neighboring towns. Since we are an hour plus away from the city, it can be hard to find qualified aids to substitute when someone is sick. So I was encouraged by a friend, who works at one of the schools, to put my name in for a Substitute Educational Assistant.

Being an Educational Assistant involves working one on one with kids who need extra help in the classroom or floating around the class to help the group in general. An E.A.'s job is not an assistant to the teacher, our focus is on helping students but sometimes if we are unoccupied we assist the teacher with photocopying, or whatnot, however, we often have our hands full.

Typical, there is a course you must take for this job, it's about a year long, although you can take more classes, in related fields. Since my area needs more help than they have qualified people, I am able to sub when someone is away. I can also apply for permanent positions when they come up, these often go to the most qualified person or those with seniority.

As a substitute, I have additional challenges, the regular aides do not have to deal with. Each school often has their own way of doing things, but in general they have a book with each aides roles, sometimes they rotate schedules. I'm given a sheet with classes, or student names, etc, and basic lists of duties. The aides often take on more work than their position calls for, because in dealing with one student, especially those with severe learning disabilities, their studies are so different from the rest of the class they often don't get as much attention from the teacher.

Meetings with other aides and teachers are supposed to keep everyone on the same page, but I frequently show up, only to find that this aide doesn't really keep current notes on what their student is studying and the teacher has no idea, because they leave the job to the aide, despite the fact the aides are not teachers.

I get to work with a wide variety of students, from Pre-K to grade 12, some physically or mentally challenged or both (often both). The range of capabilities also varies a great deal, some are kids with ADD, which generally means they learn differently, but can be very intelligent if given a little extra guidance, to those who are non-verbal, confined to wheelchairs and need assistance going to the bathroom, which we do.

Our responsibilities include but are not limited to: toileting, physiotherapy, feeding, one on one help with classes, note taking, recess and lunch supervision, detention room supervision, speech therapy, life skills. The academic part can be challenging in itself, it's been quite a number of years since I've been to school, so I often find myself relearning things I've long forgotten. Even helping the younger grades means being aware of their limitations and teaching at their level.

It can be very challenging but it is also the most rewarding job I've had so far, with the exception of raising my daughter.

123321.content:
Until I was 25 years old I had no idea what I wanted to do for a living. When people asked me what type of work I did my answer was always "I'm still deciding." It made me feel foolish. Browsing the want ads one afternoon I saw an ad stating that the city I lived in was giving the test for Police Officer. I wasted no time in signing up. How strange it turned out to be. I passed the written test, followed by a clean medical examination, the interview with the Chief and his staff and lastly an agility test. So there I was, a veteran of a long process designed to weed out the unfit. Tomorrow was my first day on the job and when I was honest with myself I realized, I had no idea what a Police Officer does during a day of work. No one does.

When I reported for work on my first day I was told to wait in the lobby, someone would be with me shortly. One wall of the lobby was all glass that looked out onto the parking lot, with the driveway coming very close to the building. A typical looking unmarked car pulled up and a detective got out, walked into the lobby. I noticed the car was riddles with small dark holes. I asked the Detective if the holes were bullet holes and he said yes, they were. "Somebody shot the car up last night." He wasn't angry, he wasn't scared, just matter of fact.

I learned early on that the job of Police Officer can't be summed up in one sentence or cliche like "I want to help people" or "I want to make a difference." You can do those things even if you're a baker, just join some active civic organizations. No, this job is different. Helping people is what you do, sometimes. Making a difference is something you do, infrequently. Most of your day is spent trying to keep people from hurting each other, or someone else. Whether it's ticketing a speeder in the hopes of changing his behavior before he kills someone, or taking in a drunk husband or boyfriend to jail for beating his wife or girlfriend, most days consist of the mundane tasks of keeping a small portion of society civil. It takes a while but eventually you realize these duties are not mundane. You begin to believe that maybe someone is alive because of something you did. Just because you don't know specifically who that is doesn't make it less real.

We all hope for the big call that results in Supreme Court rulings, newspaper articles and a ribbon to wear on your shirt pointing out you did something good. But after 20 years of police service my happiest days were the one's when I was able to help someone who couldn't help themselves.

1331.content:
When I tell people I work in State Government, they usually get very impressed. I tell them not to be. I'm basically nothing but a glorified customer service representative.

I was an English major in college, and hoped (still hope) to work in publishing some day, but I had not found a job by the time graduation rolled around, so I found myself appealing to my best friend's older brother who worked in State Government. Surprisingly enough, I was hired. (Tip for job searchers: Government usually has a lot of entry-level jobs with little skill required. Search on your State's official webpage for job listings)

My day starts with an hour drive to the "big city" where I park in a garage for $73/month and then I walk a block to my office building. Since it's government, I got an ID card the first week I started and you have to show it to the trooper when you walk in. If you forget it, like I've done a couple of times, they have to search your bag and make sure you're not carrying anything illegal (aka a weapon) into the building.

I spend my day in front of a computer in a cubicle. We are the State Government "help desk". Citizens from all over the state call about problems ranging from medicaid assistance, to complaints about what the government is doing (or not doing), and more bizarre tales that you would never believe.

Nearly 90% of the people that call ask to speak to the Governor personally. It's strange to me that people actually believe that can happen. It's like they think he has nothing better to do and so I paitently explain (many times depending on the caller) that the Governor is busy, but I would be more than willing to help them.

Another astonishing thing to me is how few people realize that the Federal Government and the State Government are two different things. I was an English major and stayed as far away from politics as possible, but even I knew that Federal Government and State Government were two different things.

Then there's the people that think you can force judges to rule in their favor. That's frustrating because I have to run through what they should have learned in middle school: the US government consists of three separate branches, etc etc.

We have "usuals"; people that call in consistently with the same complaint. Some of them don't have a good touch with reality, but others simply don't like the answer they were given. Occasionly I've had to hang up on people for cussing me out and very few times I've had to toggle a "risk" button because the person on the other line made threats.

It's very stressful at times and a couple of months ago when a minor flub hit the media, we had nonstop complaints screamed at us for hours on end. It got so bad that I had to turn off my helpline and breathe deep for a couple of minutes, trying to stop shaking and prevent myself from crying.

I'm writing this for my husband, who does not enjoy writing in the least!

He is a Paramedic working for a local area EMS (Emergency Medical Services) company. He works in a smaller city, that also covers several surrounding small towns. They have 3 different Fire/EMS stations, in which they rotate to every shift.

He works 24 hour shifts, then gets 48 hours off...unless in the event of overtime. Then it's 48 hours on and 24 off! (I'm not fond of the overtime shifts).

A typical day for him involves normal things like station duties, which are chores they have to do like clean the bathrooms, sweep the floors, wash the ambulances (inside and out). They also have to check the drugs and supplies and replenish any that are low.

They could receive an emergency call at any time. When they do, they have to drop whatever they are doing (even if they just ordered lunch)!

They rush in the ambulance, Code 3 (lights and sirens) to the scene. Sometimes it's a car wreck, sometimes a drug overdose, seizure, heart attack victim...sometimes it's an elderly person who just wants a to talk, or wants a ride to the hospital. Sometimes it's just a person with atheletes foot or someone who wants attention.

If the condition is not life threatening or serious in any way at all, the patient will often sign a refusal to go to the hospital. If the patient is in their right mind and refuses, there's nothing the medics can do about it.

Sometimes they get to the scene and the patient is deceased. Then they go through a series of trying to revive to patient. Sometimes it works...sometimes it doesn't.

In this profession, it's extremely important to have a clear outlook on death. Everybody has their time. You have to deal with death and serious injuries, whether the patient is two months old or 95 years old. You have to be mentally prepared for tragic situations.

You also have to make very quick decisions. The patient can often tell you what is wrong, and from their description, you have to decide the best course of action to take. Sometimes the patient can't talk (is a baby or unconcious), and then that's even more challenging.

Be prepared to learn a lot of medical terminology and drugs! Good math skills are important, because you have to calculate the drug doses.

To be a Paramedic, you first have to go to school to be an EMT (Emergency Medical Technician). They help out with basic things like splinting broken bones and asking questions.

The next level is an EMT-I (EMT - Intermediate). They are able to do everything the EMT does, but they can also start IVs. They cannot administer drugs, unless the Paramedic perpares it for them.

The final level is Paramedic. They do everything, including supervising/directing the EMT's and Intermediates.

It's hard work to become a Paramedic, but the job is also rewarding because you are helping people.

Intensive Care is one of the most challenging areas to work in as a nurse. Along with any of the emergency care areas (A+E, Emergency theatres etc), you have to be prepared mentally and physically, to deal with whatever comes through the door, night or day.

I gained my degree in 2001, and in the last 7 years, I have worked on surgical wards, High Dependency Units (HDUs), research, audit, and ICU.

ICU, for me, is the perfect place to be a nurse. We often have patients who stay with us for weeks at a time, and you get to know them as people and support them as they improve (or don't). You can spend individual time with families, and gain close relationships with the whole family unit. These are things that nurses do well, and want to do well, but is often outside the realms of possibility when you're working on a busy ward.

It is also mentally challenging. You have a much wider remit that on the wards: prescribing treatments within guidelines, extended roles with equipment, techniques and drugs, and a constantly challenging environment within which to practice.

The best part of all however is the team. The ICU team comprises: doctors, anaesthetists, nurses, physios, clinical support workers, dieticians, pharmacists and surgeons, and we all work together, each with our individual skills and abilities. There are no egos at play: the patient is first and foremost, and we all work towards that end.

It's a difficult job, and sometimes you'll work yourself into exhaustion throwing every possible treatment at a patient only to have them die. Sometimes your patients will be awake and afraid, knowing that they're going to die, and all you can do is be there for them. But sometimes you wave patients out the door who you never thought would make it, and that makes the struggle worthwhile.

If you want to work in an area where you will never be able to say 'I have learned everything', then healthcare is the place to be. If, as a nurse, you want the chance to blend holistic care with a demanding technical environment, then come to ICU. It's a wonderful place to be a nurse

(NB: I work in a UK ICU. ICUs in other countries do vary in their makeup and their teamwork, and the autonomy granted to nurses varies between different units, let alone countries!)

Written by my friend Jeannie, who is nearing graduation!


Someone today asked me, "What exactly is a dental hygienist?" The really simple answer is: the person who cleans your teeth at the dental office. And somehow people still get a little confused.And I get some version of this question all the time, so I thought I would enlighten everyone this afternoon. (I'm studying for a board exam and really need a study break for a few minutes.)A dental hygienist is NOT the person who suctions and hands stuff to the dentist while you get a cavity filled. That's a dental assistant. And a dental hygienist is not a dentist, although our functions are very intertwined. The difference between the two is basically this...we are geared toward disease prevention, dentists are geared toward fixing problems caused by disease. (ie., we remove tartar, remove plaque, seal teeth, apply preventive agents and educate... they restore cavities, extract teeth, etc) A hygienist is kind of like a registered nurse in the dental field. Our educational process is very simlar to that of the RN and well...they are Registered Nurses (RN), we are Registered Dental Hygienists (RDH). For anyone interested, the dental hygiene educational process is a minimum of about 3 yrs, but you can go as far as Master's Degree in Dental Hygiene. Courses include things like anatomy, physiology, microbiology, pharmacology, psychology, histology, embryology, periodontology, community health and many others. A minimum of 585 hours of clinical dental hygiene instruction (ie. clinic where you treat patients) is also a requirement. In the end, to be a dental hygienist you must graduate from a dental hygiene program, pass a National Board exam (an 8 hour written exam), Pass a clinical practical exam, pass a state licensing exam and obtain licensure from the state. It's time consuming, more difficult than it all sounds, and expensive. And I didn't say any of this to discourage anyone. I am less than 60 days from graduation and I don't regret even a second of it. In just a few months I will be a Registered Dental Hygienist and I'm pretty proud of that. Hope this little lesson answers some questions and I hope you'll check for updates as I move closer to graduation and a JOB!

And now back to studying for my National Board exam...

142211.content:
I am a Clinical Laboratory Scientist (CLS), what is also known as a Medical Technologist (MT). Every single time that I tell a family member or friend what my title is people will ask, "Oh, what is it that you actually do?" Even my cousin, who is a doctor, has no idea how I spend my working hours. We generally fall under the Pathology department a hospital's organizational scheme and nurses or doctors will just call us "lab techs". That is, if they know who we are at all.

If you've ever been in to see the doctor or been to the hospital, and you've had to have blood tests run, your sample has probably ended up in the hands of someone like me. You might have a nurse draw your blood, but more often than not you will have a Phlebotomist come by and take it. (That's a completely separate profession, but still falls under the laboratory's jurisdiction.) Once they have your blood they will take it back to the central laboratory. Depending on what type of tests your doctor has ordered it might go to one of several different sub-sections inside the laboratory. An MT/CLS can "float" around to all of the different areas in a lab or they can just work in one main area. These areas are:

Chemistry - Mostly we use green-top tubes. These have a gel separator in the bottom so that when we spin the tubes down the whole blood and other stuff (plasma proteins) are separated from the serum. This is great because we don't have to be careful not invert or mix the tubes and risk having to re-spin the specimen. Mostly we use big, expensive machines to evaluate electrolytes, liver function, basic metabolic panels, hemoglobin A1C, etc. (If you've ever watched ER and the doctor calls out 'LYTES', that patient's specimen will end up in the Chemistry part of the lab.) We also use red and purple-top tubes to do serum pregnancy tests, HIV screening, and to test serum for titers to things like Hepatitis C, etc. Toxicology is also a part of Chemistry, where we get to test people's urine for drugs. That's always fun.

Hematology - This is where your CBC's and Coagulation tests are run. Again, most of these are done on machines that can handle a high sample volume. You really have to know what your blood cells look like because as an MT you'll have to do manual differentials, where you count cells and have to know if any of the morphology (physical characteristics) is abnormal. This helps doctors diagnose leukemias and other blood cell cancers. If you find anything weird you take the slide to the Pathologist (who is a real doctor) and they make the final ruling. Coagulation tests tell the doctor if your blood has all the essential clotting factors or if you might have a platelet disorder.

Microbiology - This is where most of your urine and stool is sent to be culutred if the doctor thinks you've got a bacterial infection. You will have to know what bacteria looks like when plated on agar (special growth media) and be able to differentiate different types of bacteria based on their appearance and their growth/non-growth in different types of growth media. This is also where a bunch of your kit tests are done for Flu, Viruses, etc. Basically any suspected yeast, fungi, or bacteria are identified in this department. We also process wound cultures, your STD cultures (because they are bacteria), blood cultures, etc. A strong stomach is a must as bacteria doesn't really smell very nice. You will make a lot of stains and become very comfortable with a microscope when working in this department. Most of the definitive bacterial identification is made by a machine that has a lot of different reagents and is really smart. But you have to be able to confirm the machine's identification. Some bigger labs will also have a Virology department under the Microbiology department. But viral cultures take a long time to grow so this is probably a very laid back place to work. I wouldn't know. Most of your serology test will be done here too, depending on the size of your lab you might have a whole different department. Serology tests your serum to make sure that all of those vaccines you received are still working.

Blood Bank - This is one of the most important areas of the clinical laboratory because you could too easily kill someone if you are not very careful. This is where all of the units of blood are kept and when a patient needs blood, this is where the nurses call to scream at someone. If you know you're going in for surgery, though, you probably have blood work done two weeks ahead of time. That gives us time to do your typing and cross match and get you blood that's compatible. In case you have any rare antibodies we have to send off for special blood and hope that someone in the US has donated blood that matches yours, or we give you a really close match. If you come in and it's an emergency we just give you O neg.

There are different levels of responsibility, depending on how much education you've had. A CLS/MT must have a Bachelors degree from an accredited program. A Clinical Laboratory Technician/Medical Technician (CLT/MT) can do pretty much everything a CLS/MT does, but they only have to have an Associate degree and they get paid a little less. You can also work in the lab as a Clinical Laboratory Assistant (CLA) and you pretty much just centrifuge specimens, process send-outs and set up cultures for the CLS/CLT to read. You have to pass a Board exam to be certified by one of several certifying agencies. And you also might have to get a license, depending on what state you live in. The government regulates a lot of the who-does-what decisions. Actually, the government regulates a lot of the clinical laboratory's mandates. You can pretty much work any shift you want, especially if you work in a hospital or reference lab because they have to have Techs on hand at all hours in case a STAT specimen comes in. Days, nights, weekends, etc.

Opportunities are endless. And because there is a large shortage of qualified Techs right now, and most of the really experienced one are older and looking forward to retirement, the job outlook is great. There will never be a shortage of sick people who need lab tests. Plus, working for a hospital, I get excellent health insurance. The salary is not comparable to, say, a nurse because you don't see actual patients -- you just get exposed to their diseased body fluids. There are several other areas where you can work with additional schooling -- Histotechnology, Cytogenetics, etc. Because there are so many shifts there are a lot of supervisors and levels of management. So advancement is not hard.

I work at a pretty small lab, compared with some of the labs at bigger hospitals and reference labs like Quest and LabCorp. It's a pretty fun job. You get to hide in the lab all day and usually only interact with doctors or nurses over the phone. If you're shy and quiet like me it's really great to be able to hide behind a phone, but you still must have good communication skills. If one of your tests comes out with a critical result you'll have to call the floor and inform a nurse or doctor. About half of my job is dealing with paperwork and quality control, maintenance, etc. so that when the inspectors come (usually from The Joint Commission - I call them God) it looks like we've actually been doing our jobs. Impeccable record-keeping is a high priority because hospitals are accredited by inspection and inspectors just love to look at your records. If your hospital doesn't get re-accredited because you made a mistake then you will so get fired. That could put their Medicare/Medicaid reimbursement in jeopardy.

If you're the type of person who took Biology and Chemistry and liked the lab parts for all of the fun little experiments, this profession might be for you. Keeping patients' tests results confidential is of the utmost importance. Even if they're your family or friends, you can't say a word to anyone-even them-if you happen to see their results. I like to think of myself as one of the unsung heroes of medical diagnostics, but some people might see me as just a button-pusher. Either way, my job is always interesting and the other Techs become something of a second family because you all have to help each other out. Feel free to e-mail me if you want to know more.

14222.content:
There are lots of different types of nurses' aides, depending on where you work and what you do. I just happen to work in the local burn unit.

Working where I do, I have a lot more responsibility than most other techs. I'm not just the cute little girl that passes out the lunch trays or hands you a cool washcloth. Nah, you're not that lucky. I'm the one in the green scrubs who does your dressing change (causing you excruciating pain regardless of your pain meds), changes your linens, suctions you if you've got a trach. Yes, I do pass out lunch trays and take out the trash, but that's just the low end of my job.

A typical day? I get to work at about 6:45 AM. I get report from the night tech, check the board to see which patients the doctors want to see that morning and when, and then set up my carts for my dressing changes and roll out any torso dressings. Once that's done, the nurse and I set about doing our dressing changes. We cut open the dressings and remove them, wash the burn wounds, then reapply the dressings. Four days after a skin graft, we take out staples. Naturally, this is painful--burn injuries are one of few health care fields in which you hurt the patient to heal them.

Dressing changes usually take all morning, sometimes longer if a patient is getting into the bathtub. After that, we get a breather for lunch, and resume the usual tasks of medicating, cleaning, and generally taking care of our patients.

Our unit is small, only nine beds. But wow! Nine beds take a lot of effort when it's the burn unit. On days we get an admission, things get more than a little hectic. After we get the call, the patient will sometimes go to the ER for evaluation. If it's a bad burn, they come straight upstairs to us. Then begins the process of debriding (getting the dead tissue off) and cleaning the wounds. Fortunately for them, most of them are intubated and sedated by this time and don't feel it and won't remember it later. Their body temperature is critical and we do everything we can to warm them up, since after burn injuries the body temperature plummets. I've had patients so cold when they came in (still alive, yes) the temperature wouldn't even register on the thermometer. If we can get them warm and get fluids into them, most of the time we can save them.

Of course, on occasion, patients do pass away. It's always very sad for us because we quickly attach to our patients, especially me. We treat the patient with dignity and respect, even after death, and allow the family whatever they need to say goodbye to their loved one.

I love my job. It's exciting. I'm always learning something new, experiencing new things. Yeah, it's difficult, especially when we get pediatric patients. But I get to do so much good in my job and affect so many lives positively that the good far outweighs the bad.

Well, there was my breather. Back to work.

In my country, we get to decide what we want to be when we grow up, at the very mature age of sixteen. Those who choose to pursue a college education, prepare for the exams to get into university and end up some four, five or six years later graduating, ready to work in the wonderful world of the chosen profession. Or not. Unemployment is a tough opponent.
When I was in the tender and, as I said, mature age of sixteen, I chose to be a doctor. We would very often hear about MSF (medecins sans frontiers- french for doctors without borders ) and learn about the courage, selflessness and love these people spread in areas of the world that were getting tested by wars, famine and other difficult situations. These people were my heroes. I never questioned their dedication, their putting others above themselves and the great mind and soul strength that they had. They were the live examples of giving, caring and loving. They would care for sick children, starved people, people that were getting hunted and uprooted from their countries. So, I decided this was what I wanted to do. Become a doctor and join the MSF and travel around the world to save people.
I became a doctor, but I didn't join MSF. I had gotten married and had children. It is hard to leave your family and go around the world when you have kids. Or maybe it is fear or cowardice. Or both, I still don't know. And I still think of these people in MSF with awe.
What eased me for feeling useless for not joining MSF, was one of my favorite TV series, ER. For those of you who don't know it, I have to say it is the most accurate medical drama I have ever seen, and I have watched a lot of them, believe me! I was watching it while I was studying and it made me realize that there are many sick people who need help and who are living next to us. Yesterday I had the best customer I've ever helped. I think I'll call her Sunny. All honey-blonde highlights and bright eyes, she breezed into the shop with a smile on her face and her husband in tow, and when we called out a greeting, she responded cheerfully.

Both of the other girls on shift were already helping other customers, so when Sunny plucked a pair of pants off the rack and started eyeing the size on the tag, I detached myself from the counter on which I'd been leaning and went over to help her find her size. She asked me what I'd recommend pairing with the pants she liked, so I picked out a few different tops and started a dressing room for her.

She loved the outfits I put together for her, and what at first seemed like a simple mission for a single pair of pants soon became a full-blown shopping extravaganza. After she confessed to me that though she loves fashion and funky looks, she tends to dress rather conservatively because she doesn't really know how to put the looks together, I started bringing her a few other outfits that I thought would look cute on her. She loved almost everything I showed her, and so did her husband. While she tried things on and he waited, I brought him a bottle of water. Sunny loved our current collection, and also wanted to see some pants from our new collection, which we'd just gotten in and hadn't even put out in the shop yet. I showed her a couple of pairs of gorgeous pants, and she fell in love with them and took them in both colors.

After we'd bagged up her twenty items and run her credit card through, Sunny told me how much fun she'd had. She'd been really fun for me to help, too--so pleasant, sweet, open to new ideas, and funny--so I told her that. We parted on great terms. She made my day.

Customers like that are one in a hundred, but they make all the rest of the job worthwhile. I didn't like her because she bought nearly a thousand dollars worth of clothing, I liked her because she was so charming and fun to help that it was almost like shopping with a girlfriend.

I've gotten to the point where I know there's nothing I love as much as writing, nothing I love enough to commit to doing as a career besides writing, and nothing else I'm particularly good at except for writing. Unfortunately for me, it's very hard to sustain oneself by writing, and so now I'm a full-time retail sales associate at a semi-upscale ($30 T shirts, $100 sweaters, $300 suits) womenswear shop. I work with some really great girls, most of them around my age, some of whom have become very good friends, and their company makes my job a lot more enjoyable than it would be otherwise: every day we have moments that are more like freewheeling parties than actual work.

Of course, there is the actual work. When things are slow, we make sure the clothes are neatly folded or hung, the hangers are all facing the same way and are all appropriate to the clothes they hold, the mannequins are current and clean, and the shop is well-stocked. We also write thank-you notes to all our customers (company policy, and we get a bonus if we do all our thank-you notes). Selling is stressful. The company has a very strict sales performance standard: usually we have to sell, on average, at least $100 per hour over each two-week pay period. We only get commission on whatever we sold above that base $100/hour standard. If we don't make that goal, it's called going in the hole, and it's very bad. No commission, and going in the hole two times a row (meaning, selling badly for an entire month) means getting fired. In addition, if we're in the hole, we have to sell almost ten times that much above our usual goal the next pay period round in order to get out of it and make commission. On any given day, you'll see at least two of us hunched over the schedule sheet, calculator in hand, figuring out how much we need to sell, then going to the computer to look at our numbers in the clerk performance report.

The company's dress code is strict. We always have to wear the company's clothes (luckily for us, we get a %50 discount, and the clothes are nice--my wardrobe's improved a lot since I started working at the shop), nice (read: uncomfortable but good-looking) shoes, and always should have neat hair and makeup. A lot of grooming and a lot of aching feet are involved in working there. For most of us, though, it's fun. We just had a new shipment of clothes come in, and it was like Christmas, opening up all the boxes, seeing items we loved, and planning what we want to buy.

In some ways, working at this shop in the mall is like being in high school again. There are cliques and crushes (almost every girl in the shop has a crush on one of the guys working at a neighboring shop), gossip and juvenile office politics (one of the girls I work with has gotten on everyone else's bad side by poaching others' customers, being too aggressive, and being kind of rude besides)

I'm at the point where I know that the only thing I really love, the only thing I love doing enough to commit to for the rest of my life, and the only thing I'm any good at is writing. Unfortunately for me, it's difficult to pay bills and keep myself housed and fed on writing alone. Hence the day job. As things go, it could be much worse.

151.content:
I always wanted to be a writer. I dreamed of somehow just "becoming" one. I did not realize that writing was work--hard work! But I get ahead of myself.

I went to a small high school and there were not many extracurricular activities other than sports. I wished we had a newspaper or a creative writing club. In English class, we did some writing, but it was mostly expository themes. Boring! My teacher frustrated me because she told me I couldn't write, and I was scoring 13/20 on her grading rubric--an F! *sigh*

But I did not let her negativity destroy my dream.

I did have a chance to write a tiny column about school for the local weekly newspaper, but I didn't have any freedom--the article was always approved by the principal. Nonetheless, it was exciting for me to be published.

I decided to major in journalism when I went to college. An English major had too much reading to do and I was avoiding the classics like the plague at that time. Journalism seemed to fit what I thought I could do. I wanted to get good grades, and so I decided to do something that would be easy.

I hated it.

I liked the writing part; I hated the interviewing part. I am not a people person.

However, I did not change my major. I plugged along, doing what I needed to do to maintain my A average. I enjoyed my history and anthropology classes a lot more, and probably should have changed my major. I had my parents' constant nagging about finding a job, though, so I stayed in the major I chose.

I worked for the college newspaper, but did not like it very much. My other jobs as a library assistant and as a peer tutor were much more satisfying and rewarding--not to mention they were easy and had a lot of free time.

During my junior year, I had to find a paid internship for that summer as a requirement to graduate with that major. I had worked at a small weekly newspaper during the previous summer, but that wasn't enough time to count, according to the professors, so I was desperate to find something that would count.

My dad had some connections at an industry publication in which he advertised, and he helped me get a paid internship with the magazine. I did have to interview for the position and everything, though. It was not "handed" to me, by any means.

That job was mostly creating ads for the magazine. I learned to use Pagemaker and CorelDraw and some paste-up skills. (Back then, in 1993, some magazines were still pasting up their layouts.) I did not write any original articles or anything, but I did typeset already-written material.

I loved it. I did not have to deal with people and I had some creativity.

So, when I went back to school in the fall, I took a layout and design class offered by the journalism department, and one that was offered by the business department. I remember that my professors tried to dissuade me from taking the one offered by the business department, but I was not about to miss my opportunity.

I did well in both, and as my senior year drew to a close, I began looking for a permanent job--in layout and design. Although I was not a graphic arts major, I still had a good background in the practical side of layout. I think that my internship was the most important skill I gained at college.

I was hired at a printing company where I learned QuarkXPress and used Adobe Illustrator to do layout and design. Mostly, I did the layout. Customers submitted their own designs. I made a variety of products: newsletters, magazines, newspapers, books, flyers, business cards, envelopes, and the like. Some materials were still pasted up physically with wax, but the majority of jobs were pasted up electronically on the computer. (This was in 1994.) Deadlines were important to meet and I was constantly under stress, trying to meet them. Sometimes, the customers were picky and I had to re-set things a hundred times to satisfy them.

I worked there for about nine months at $7 an hour. At that time, I thought the pay was enormous. It was more than I had ever made before, but it was still barely enough to scrape by. Thankfully, my parents still helped me out by paying for my car insurance.

But as with all jobs, there were people I got along with and people I did not like. I was moved to a different shift, which I did not like, and morale at the company was low. Plus, this company was three hours away from my family and I wanted to move closer to them.

I found another job at a college book typesetting company, and have been there for almost ten years. I started out at $7.25, but have now more than doubled that pay rate. I don't have to deal with customers, but my job is VERY detail-oriented. I have to follow lots of conflicting instructions and remember lots of different things while producing pages. Although I do not deal directly with customers, my boss is very exacting and perfectionistic--it is his company, after all. I am also a perfectionist, so this quality helps me stay focused and remember the details.

Each book has a set of instructions which lists the design parameters. I have to follow them to the letter and sometimes change things on the fly, when the design is modified at the last minute.

To do this job, you need more than just a working knowledge of page layout programs such as Pagemaker or QuarkXPress. In fact, you need many skills, such as listening, following directions, thinking ahead to the next stage of the process, planning, intimate knowledge of design principles (which I learned on the job), how to use a ruler, how to convert measurements, paying attention to detail, and various other things that you really can't learn in a classroom setting.

In spite of how easy it sounds, I come home from work exhausted at the end of the day. Thinking takes its toll. My hands often ache from typing or using the mouse all day. My neck hurts too, and sometimes my eyes feel strained from staring at a monitor all day long. I sometimes have to work overtime if certain books need to be finished by a certain day.

It is a good job and I am treated well here. I often feel lucky to have found this job that suits me so well--but at the same time, I feel chained to it.

Having this job does free me to pursue my writing dreams. I have plenty of free time after work to follow through. I just wish I wasn't so tired! LOL

If you think you might be interested in pursuing a career in page layout and design, I suggest you major in graphic arts. Even if you can't draw, you will get the background you need in design and other things. I feel handicapped sometimes because I did not have those classes. If I did go back to college, I would major in graphic arts. However, if you do major in graphic arts, remember that simple is best.

Some of the job is muzzling and restraining that 200 pound aggressive rottweiler that would love nothing better than to eat your face. Most patients fall somewhere in the middle. If you want to be a phyical therapist, you better love people, and love to go to school!

I have been a physical therapist for over 20 years. I have a Master's Degree in Science. Entry level for physical therapy is currently a Master's Degree, but may soon become a Doctorate level. That means you are in college for at least 6 years. Then you have to take a board exam in physical therapy and pass before you can be licensed.

Physical therapists help people recover functional abilities after an illness, and accident, or from a genetic problem. We work in nursing homes, rehabilitation hospitals, acute care hospitals, home care, school systems, industrial sites, fitness centers and private practice. We also teach, and work in outpatient clinics. We treat all ages of people from birth to death.

Salaries start at about $35,000 and peak at about $65,000, unless you have your own business, then you may earn over $80,000. You usually work day shift, some weekends and holidays. Job security was sketchy in the 1990's, it has improved over the last four years.

PT school is difficult to get into, very demanding and competitive. You have to be skilled in communication, sciences and some math. You can not be squeemish. I had to dissect a human cadaver, and do other unpleasant clinicals in school.

You have to be a patient person(get the pun?)willing to work with sick people and their families. I have patients who are celebrities; others from rural areas who can't read or write.

It is not a glamourous job. I have seen every body excretion to ooze out of every crevice you can imagine. We have been bit, kicked, punched, hit, cussed at, spit at and reviled. On the other hand, we are thanked, blessed, appreciated and have made lasting friends with our patients.

It is a physically demanding job. You have to be in good physical shape to perform the job safely. Some of my patients weigh over 500 pounds! Yet, a tiny 80 pound patient can cause your back more grief.

Would I go into PT again if I had a choice? No, I think if I were to stay in medicine, I would have been a physician. If I have to be in school that long, I may as well be the top of the food chain.
