An Advocate for a non-profit organization - what is that, you might wonder?

To be honest, my job is not the typical job that most people will come across or even consider as an avenue for employment, but I can speak to the fact that it is one of the most rewarding jobs a person can do.

There is no such thing as a typical day for me, as each and every day, I have people walk through my door that need assistance in a wide variety of issues. I can deal with issues that range from difficulties accessing government services, to assisting people in filling out forms, attending court with people who need that extra body there as a support, to contacting and sitting in meetings with elected officials.

Advocacy. Advocate. Words which don't mean a whole lot to many people, and invoke fear in others. For the people that fear me, it's usually because they have a vision of an advocate as someone who comes in and gets the job done at all costs, and probably sacrificing a few people along the way. Not so, I say. My job involves taking the time to listen to what someone's issues are, exploring a little bit below the surface issues to make sure there are any underlying issues contributing to the problem, and then acting as a mediator or facilitator to resolve the issue. A good piece of what I do is not even in my job description - it's taking the time to just listen.

I will attend meetings with people who have disabilities. Often they are having a hard time conveying what it is they need and how it is that what is being offered just doesn't quite meet this need. The easiest way to explain my role in these situations is to explain that I am a translator - I translate from people-speak to bureaucracy-speak and back again.

I can attend meetings that are not individual advocacy issues. These meetings - committee meetings, are to assist people who provide a service to ensure that the needs and concerns of people with disabilities are being met and that systemic barriers are not being put in place that will hinder the individuals from accessing services.

I field a lot of questions from the public and from other agencies about where and how to access services. I must have a comprehensive knowledge of what is out there in the real world, and I must also be willing to admit when I don't know about a service. This lack of knowledge then sets into motion the "I got to find it" mode.

So, to sum up, if it is possible to do so - I field phone calls from individuals who need one-to-one help accessing services, resolving issues; meet one on one with these individuals and attend meetings with them; sprovide information to the general public and agencies on different programs and services; attend board and committee meetings; and whatever else may come my way. I need to be aware of local, provincial and federal laws and the respective services they offer.

Skills and abilities that a person needs to have to get into this field? People will know it if they want to do it. Many individuals who do what I do have a background in Social Services or Social Work. Compassion and empathy are a plus, if not a must. And, last but not least, you need to be flexible and creative, but be able to think in a logical way. You also must be able to think outside of the box. True, much of this sounds like a paradox, but it is possible to have all these traits rolled up into one individual. Most importantly, as a person gets started in this field, these traits and skills are something which is built upon as you explore and develop into the job.

Clear as mud? I hope not. Maybe the title of my chapter should actually be: People Problem-Solver

An incision was made in his anterior neck to accommodate a spit fistula, and now my patient sits on the edge of his bed holding a pink basin to his throat to catch the river of blood that flows from it. I watch as if in slow motion as sheer terror replaces the hope that had once been in his eyes, and he silently pleads with me to help him.

Oh, my God! I think, as I turned to run out of the room. I need to go get the nurse! Then it dawns on me...I AM the nurse! I settle for a more experienced nurse, and within moments I have the charge nurse, a respiratory therapist and the patient's physician at his bedside.

My patient survived the night, but his cancer metastasized and he died a few weeks later.

Many years have passed since that fateful evening, but I have never forgotten the lessons it taught me. As a registered nurse, my job is to make my patient's day (or night, as the case may be) a little better...make them smile, answer their lights promptly, listen to their concerns, and ease their pain. On those rare occasions when I'm assigned a dying patient, I work with that person's doctor to make their passing as comfortable and pain-free as possible, for the patients as well as the ones they leave behind.

There's more than just a sick body on the bed in front of me; there is a human being, and human beings have many levels of need: emotional, physical, spiritual, psychological, social, etc. Patients look to their nurse to be their therapist, caregiver, friend, priest, and confidant all rolled into one, and we promise you the best care we are capable of providing for the 8 or 12 hours you are entrusted to our care.

I am currently a Professional Ice Hockey Player, and I couldn't ask for anything better in terms of an occupation... The job is so big, and entails so much, that it would take a full size novel to just get through a day... Also, because of the schedule we go through busy days and slow days, so I may write about multiple days in different chapters. Don't worry though. I'll always include a "Different occupation" button so you don't have to sit through my ramble if you don't want to. :)

Anyways, after that rather long preface, I present to you The Life of an Athlete.

I'll tell you about a gameday, because those are always busy. An athlete's life is usually filled with little superstitions and rituals, that the public just can't see. Such is the case with me. I actually saw this story and kept a journal of my days for a few months, so I could give you an accurate feel. My day starts at about seven AM. I wake up and get dressed as fast as possible. After grabbing the closest thing to eat, I head out the door. I head to the rink for an early practice, and arrive there only minutes later. (There are benefits to living close to the rink)

Anyway, I head in the VIP entrance of the arena. It's a massive building, constructed specifically for my team only four years ago. It seats 10,000 people, and it comes fully equipped with lounges, restaurants, and stuff like that. I love the place, and I spend most of my time there.

So I'll make the ten minute walk to the complex entertaining by listening to music on my phone. I have different music for each situation, so I'll play different stuff depending on if it's gameday, I'm starting or finishing a game, what time it is, ect. On this particular day, at 7:36 AM, it's Ariana Grande. Laugh all you want, but most hockey players are actually big sweethearts on the inside, and we're compared to big teddy bears by people who know us best.

I'm one of the biggest personalities in my league, meaning that I constantly have to deal with media attention. The cameras are everywhere, filming for various channels, websites, shows, ect. I've learned to ignore them and go about my business, because that's all they want to film.

I keep walking down the bright hallway to the home team's complex. Let me stop for a moment to explain a complex to people who aren't familiar with it. Those of you who know about sport complexes can just proceed to the next paragraph. In each arena, there are two complexes. One for the home team, and one for the visitors. They are restricted areas for only media, team personnel, league personnel, and VIPs. They contain things such as team gyms, dressing rooms, doctor's rooms, equipment rooms, ect.

Anyway, I complete the ten minute walk to my own complex, which is conveniently located on the exact opposite side of the arena from the VIP entrance. The first thing I do is head into the dressing room. Most of my teammates are already there, preparing for the morning skate. I head to my stall, and begin to change. After putting on my skates, pants, leg armor, and socks, I grab seven packs of gum from the table in the center of the room. I'm not too picky about what brand I get, but it HAS to be mint flavored. It's one of my little superstitions that I can't bear to ignore. I have to take seven before each morning skate, because I've done that every day since I was 14. It's partially a matter of ritual, and partially because I chew a lot of gum. I like to tell people I'm addicted to it, so I don't feel so bad about the crap I'm swallowing. In truth, most hockey players chew tobacco, and gum is the only thing that keep me away from it.

Next I'll get a member of the equipment staff to grab me five water bottles. Three filled with water, one with white Gatorade, and one with coconut water. I'll line them all up on the right side of my stall, with the water at the front, then the coconut water, then the Gatorade. This makes me drink the water first, which is what I want. There is actually reasoning behind this ritual, because the water is what I need right then. This is for a couple of reasons. The first of them being that water stimulates blood flow, therefor making you more quick, agile, and receptive. That's just what I need going into a skate shortly after waking up. The second reason is that drinking water is clinically proven to loosen your muscles, and that's also important for me. The third reason is a branch off of the first, but it's that the more blood is flowing through your veins, and the faster it flows, the more ability you have to self generate heat, which is important before going to spend 1-2 hours on the ice.

The coconut water is for as soon as I get off the ice. By that time, the water should be gone, and the equipment staff should have replaced it with bottles on the left side of my stall. I'd like to pause the story and recognize the work they do as well, because they're so great. They know my rituals, and accommodate them. They work day and night to make my job easier, and they have a very neat job. I know because I used to be one.

Back to the coconut water. It's for right after the skate, because it contains the necessary nutrients to refuel your body, such as proteins. It's also enhanced with minerals to spike your on ice performance. And the last of the drinks is the Gatorade. Most people drink it right before a game, but that's the wrong decision to make. In truth, the amount of sodium in Gatorade is far too much for the amount of liquid used in the drink. That means it will do three things to you, and I'll explain them below.

The first thing it does is dehydrate you because of the salt. That in itself is a problem, because it makes you tired, sluggish, and in some cases, faint, dizzy, hallucinogenic, prone to convulsions, and nauseous.

The second of the effects is equally bad. The salt used in Gatorade is cheap, and therefor bad quality. It's artificial salt, meaning that it doesn't break down as easily. Even though it doesn't look, taste, or feel like it's actual grains of salt, everything is made of particles, and this salt is made of substantially larger particles than natural salt, such as sea salt. What that means is that when it gets into your blood flow, it will still be in small crystal form due to the longer dissolving time required. The downside to the crystals being in your blood flow is that is may actually make small slits in your veins as it travels through them, and the slits will take a while to heal. Even though they're not visible, they do leak blood, resulting in the side effects of dehydration all over again.

The third thing happens much later, usually 5-10 hours after you drink the Gatorade. The sugars in it are converted into the carbohydrate form that you need to enhance your performance, resulting in enhanced abilities. To insure that I get the bad side effects out of the way first, and the good ones right at game time, I drink the Gatorade sometime around noon, and just make sure to drink as much water as possible from that moment onward.

Anyway, I'll cut the chapter short here, but if you would like to read about the rest of the day, just click the "More hockey" option and I should have it updated tomorrow. In the next portion, I'll include more about practice, lunch, preparation, and possibly the game. :)
15111111111112.title: The Life of an Athlete

151111111111212.content:
Oh yes. I'm working. I get up at 0445 a.m. to catch a bus to make it to work by 0700.

Taking that damn parking bus always makes me late" I grumble to myself as I race to clock in on time. "Stupid time clock," I continued my musings on the elevator up to my floor,” Why did I get a 4 year degree, thousands of hours of continuing ed and certification in my specialty to be treated like factory worker? Nursing is so schizoid."

It's 0700 and I just make it to clock in and grab my assignment. I look to see its Baby Boy C again. I feel the sigh of resignation come out. Baby C was a little 26 weeker (born 61/2 month early) who weighed about 750 grams (about 1.7lbs). Sometimes 26 weekers do well and have minimal problems. Those are the ones you read about in Reader's Digest or see on Oprah. Some die. And some like Baby Boy C come out sick and stay sick for a long time and become “chronic". Chronic babies have lungs that are damaged from being on the ventilators. They need the vents to save their lives but in the long run it also damages the lungs.
Baby C also has the chronic personality. He is extremely irritable with any change or sudden touch. For most of his life, 9 times out of 10, touch has meant lab draws, IV starts or vital signs interrupting perfectly good sleep. So it’s hard to blame him, but it also means that it's hard to comfort him. That’s why I sighed. He is a hard baby to like.

My other baby is a "feeder grower" which means the baby is in an Isolette, on oxygen getting tube feeds just waiting to gain weight. Baby Girl A parents don't speak English only Spanish which makes teaching and updating a challenge for me. And I have first admission.

I get report from the night nurse who has been here since 1900 (7 p.m.) last night. 12-hour shift are normal for my unit and most units in my hospital. Tracy tells me that Baby C had a good night. He is on high flow nasal cannula oxygen and only had 2 "fits" last night. Fits being he cries so hard that he turns blue drops oxygen saturation and needs extra oxygen and holding. Anyone not knowing Baby C would think that there is a major problem when he has his fits especially looking at the numbers on his heart monitor. But what he really needs is the extra O2 and a strong hug.

Baby A also had a good night and is on the fast track to be transferred to the Level 2 nursery which is a step down from the intensive care unit.

After checking charts and checking for meds to give, I begin cleaning. I clean the Isolette, the crib, the monitors, the charts and the chairs in my area. Surprised? Don't be. Alot of hospitals are cleaning the 'bunker" or patient care area every shift to cut down on infections. Medicare soon will not be paying for certain hospital acquired infections. So this practice is as much for the hospital survival as for the patient. Most of our babies are receiving Medicare. The average cost of hospital stay for 500-700gramer is $224,000 so it's smart for everyone. There is only one PCA or patient care assistant in the unit so each nurse cleans her/his work area.

Not an easy thing to get done while I am working around interns, residents and attending who want to see the charts and the babies before rounds. I have no problem with this except I tell them all if they wake Baby C they will be sorry.
"My policy is you wake, you take" I tell the intern. "Tracy just got him to sleep after his latest fit at 0600.' The intern, who has her stethoscope poised, takes a step back to see if I was serious. I give her my Major Houlihan stare and she backs off.


First rounds include doing hands on assessment of the baby giving meds, doing 0800 labs, if ordered and feeds. Baby Girl A assessment looks good. "Mmmm...... heart, lungs, bowels all sound good, skin color looks good, IV site looks ok. May need a restart later if we don't increase feeds." I keep a running commentary in my head so that I can remember what to chart in the assessment when I am done.

And I am done just in time as dear Baby Boy C is having his first fit. "Wow 70% O2 sat little guy" I croon to the baby as I turn up his O2. He probably has a wet diaper because his heart rate is ok. He will not come back up without me changing him and holding him. I quickly change his diaper and swaddle him and hold him up in a bear hug. "You little faker!!" I laugh at him. He has immediate calmed and his color is returning to normal. O2 sat 97% He looks at me and smiles as I wean his O2 back to his normal range. I wonder how long I need to hold him till I can put him down and get his breakfast. Omygod! It’s getting late 0930. I haven't charted his neighbor's assessment, done this boy's assessment and his breakfast is due now.
Fortunately, Jennifer one our volunteers comes to my bedside. "Any babies to hold?” she asked. I thrust Baby C into her arms and help her settle into the rocker. With any luck she can hold him while I feed and do an abbreviated assessment and I can get caught up. I run to the breast milk/formula room. I grab his special high cal formula from the fridge. I draw up the amount into a 60cc (2oz) syringe. I check my brain card (a card I took notes on during report check out) for meds and lab work. "Cool. Not to late for 0900 meds" I think as I gather them from the med cart.

After I give my meds and finish Baby C's modified assessment, I am called to rounds. "I can go after I hang this feeding. Can someone else go?" I ask the other nurses in my area. Brad volunteers and grabs his charts for the rounding room.Hang a feeding? Yes Baby C, though now calm, is still working too hard with his breathing and the rate is above what I consider safe for bottle feeding. Merry, the charge nurse says it’s like running a marathon as you suck through a straw. So for feedings, he has a G-tube: a surgically placed tube through the wall of his abdomen to his stomach. It saves the baby calories he would be using for breathing and eating to grow on. I start the warmed formula through a syringe pump as Jennifer continues to hold and cuddle him.

"They're ready for you in rounds,' says Brad as he cruises back to his assignment.
I smile and thank him as I gather my charts. I tell Brad to keep an ear out for Baby C as he is still eating and being held and Baby A should be fine. "Will do" he replies.

As I walk to the rounding room, I muse over Brad's latest witticism about nursing after a bad day with demanding parents "You know I got into nursing to help people and to make more money than being a waiter. What I didn't know was that nursing was wait staff without the tips. 'Get me a pillow, get me a drink of water, my baby is wet. Aren't you going to change him?' Not a please or thank you in the bunch and I'm here to teach them how to change diapers especially if they're 15!" I smiled ruefully as I entered the rounding room. There was alot of truth in that rant.

Rounds in the NICU are not like on TV. It's not kindly doctors in white coats with adoring interns floating from beside to beside. Everyone rounds in one room. Everyone includes: the attending, the fellows, the residents, the interns, the pharmacist, the dietitian, the social worker, the nurse and sometimes the parents. The atmosphere in the room seems like controlled chaos at times but everyone wants the best possible outcome for the babies.

The intern starts the ball rolling by giving out the vital stat of the day before, lab values, how baby did overnight. If something has changed since the intern has seen the baby or I notice something in my assessment, this the time for me to speak up. The attending listens, makes notes and guides the intern into making the plan of care for the day. Everyone gets a chance to ask questions or make suggestions. This is when routine orders are written so it saves time. Rounding on my two kids can take as long as 30 minutes between presentation and interruptions from other nurses with more critical babies who need orders or to ask questions.

I finally get done with rounds and return to my area. No major changes on my kids, so I can just cruise through the day, I hope.

Sigh.... Baby A's parents are here. I gotta get the translator for updates and teaching and look at the time. I'm missing lunch again. Look, we can talk later. What are you doing after lunch or do you actually get a lunch?
151111111111212.title: A Day in the Life of a Neonatal Nurse......

Once two guys from the local CID (Criminal Investigation Department) came to talk to me [over a mix-up with my bus-pass; I don't mix with all those secret agents, murderers and pirates, anymore] and. when I told them I was a Hand-Knitter, they asked how I managed to fit in all the fingers. Well, you know cartoonists generally draw only three.

So, you want to know what it was like:

There were thirty of us in a room like a classroom, with a supervisor at the front. We all had proper wooden three-drawer office desks with a lifting flap. We had a tea towel on the desk, to protect the knitting from contamination, and another to protect our clothing from shed yarn. We weren't supposed to talk loudly enough to spoil the Compilers' concentration (but the Compilers only stopped talking long enough to complete tricky calculations). Occasionally, the supervisor changed the layout of the desks or moved everybody round, just like a teacher in school. My friend and I sat next to each other and talked all day long so the supervisor moved us to opposite ends of the room, but she had to move us back because we shouted to each other, across all the intervening people. All the knitters and compilers were women. So were the designers. All the managers were men, and the manufacturing, warehouse and clerical offices were mixed. We were the prestige department and all the tours came through our room, including a coachload of Japanese Craft Shop owners.

We were allowed to read while knitting, and write shopping lists, because it kept us quiet. I wrote letters, quite a few poems and a couple of stories. As long as I kept the pad under the corner of the cloth, the supervisor couldn't catch me and, as long as I produced the work (and kept quiet), she didn't want to. We had to have a pad, to keep track of rows and stitches, so it was easy just to keep another pad next to it for story notes, etc.

So, I hear you ask, what were we doing as our paid job? Well, all those sweaters you wear, the good quality ones, have to be designed and knitted. Knitting yarn manufacturers pay designers to design them, Compilers to write the instructions, Maths Checkers to check that the instructions work and Knit Checkers to check that the garment will come out like the designer's sketch. The completed garments were photographed for the cover of the instruction leaflets. And the whole Publications section existed to encourage people to buy our knitting yarn rather than that of a rival manufacturer.

We didn't just knit, and it wasn't all garments. There was a six-month training period because we had to learn how to do all the different types of plain and fancy knitting stitches and fabrics, different types of shaping, different methods of joining the pieces together, as well as crochet and some embroidery. It was apprentice training, although without recognition, and our work was classed as semi-skilled manual labour.

It was a good environment; friendly and free, with only occasional time-pressure, and I sometimes miss it. One day, I hope there will be recognition for the skill which goes into this work, and certficates to prove it has worth. After all, people will always need clothes and some people will always want to make them.

I can't knit a jumper for a man with a 46 inch chest in under a month and, these days, I wouldn't want to start one. But I can knit anything I want and adapt commercial instructions to suit my needs. Four Christmases ago, I knitted a glove puppet which every kid recognised as Pikachu (using instructions for Postman Pat's cat). I still learn new stitches when I want to. And I intend to develop a course to pass on this knowledge, just like craftsmen always used to.

Knitting allows expression for our creative side and, if anyone was offered a paid job doing a task they'd choose as a hobby, it wouldn't take too much thought to decide whether to take it.

Greetings one and all, Sherri the Writer here. My day job is as a Program Assistant. Specifically, I license landscape architects and soil classifiers. I've been doing this since July 1999.

First, let me explain what these professions are. Landscape architects are people who design outdoor spaces. Like an architect does the inside, landscape architects do the outside. You can see their work in parks, playgrounds, golf courses, and any outdoor area that is designed for public use. Soil classifiers basically so site evaluations of the soil in an area where people typically want to do development work. These are very simple definitions for complex professions. In fact, that's why they're licensed - because they're so specialized.

Running two licensure programs is administrative work, meaning I sit behind a computer and push paper most of the time. It's not bad work. It's great getting to know people and help them accomplish their professional goals. In fact, I think helping others achieve their dreams rubs off on you after a while - I know seeing their dedication and hard work motivated me to pursue my dream of being a writer.

My typical day would probably be considered dull for most people - I come to work and get behind the computer to check my E-mail (that's how I get most of my correspondence). Usually it's processing applications, checking on applications in progress, verifying paperwork for people applying for licenses out of state, or processing license renewals if it's December - February. Each program has an advisory council that meets two to four times a year, and I usually organize those meetings and do the administrative follow up for them. Mainly, this is issuing license since people are reviewed and approved for licensure at these meetings, and following up on complaints (which are rare) and any other issues that we feel is important to the program.

Twice a year I administer the registration exam for landscape architects. This takes a lot of organization and coordinating. Not only do I have to process applications for the exam, but I have to collect the money for the exam, place the exam order, and work with the coordinator for the site where we give the exam to get a contract in place for the next exam administration (I have an agreement set up with a certain place). Once the actual exam rolls around, however, it's pretty easy work. I pass out the exams, fill out some paperwork, and sit quietly for five hours while they take the exam. Since I can't have anything with a computer memory chip in the room with me (meaning no cell phones or laptops), I usually read or cross stitch to pass the time. Then once they're done, I check the booklets, confirm the paperwork, and pack it all up to ship when they're done. Giving the exam is usually a pretty easy day. The only bad part is that testing starts at 8:00 A.M. so I have to be at the test site by 7:30 A.M. to set up and in case they need to see me before testing starts. I'm not a morning person, so this is usually a cruel fate to an otherwise good day for me.

Once a year, I get to speak to the professional practice class at one of the state universities about the licensure law and the registration examination for landscape architecture. I remember I was so nerfous the first time I did it, but I'm getting used to it. It's good to meet the students and the professors in the program to get a different perspective to the profession.

Most of my days are computer and paperwork, but that's ok. I actually have a bachelor's degree in psychology, but have found that this fits well with that degree. I still get to help people, even if it's in a much different way than I envisioned in college. In fact, I fell into administrative work when I decided to postpone graduate school to get married. I think the Lord was leading me in the right direction. This job has been such a great fit for me that I've decided to stay and pursue my writing instead of the advanced degree. So in the end, it all works out. I'm happy with my job and pursuing my dreams while helping others achieve their own. I feel like I'm in the ultimate win-win situation.

And you just can't beat that!

"I guess you could say the same for this job too, tho. The best part of driving tho, is that I like to meet different people."

"I see the same people all of the time tho." She said in an exasperated voice.

I could tell she was tired. Tired of working on her computer all day, so that her plans could be put into working action. It wasn't that long of a ride, only three miles, but I could tell she was going to take advantage of a bubble bath when she got inside of her house. Something to relax her. I could use a bubble bath too, come to think of it (giggles).

"You're the first lady cab driver I've seen," she said with a little surprise in her voice. "Are there many lady drivers?"

A recruiter is under constant pressure to close positions. Its always about numbers. In the competitive job market, the supply never seems to surpass demand when it comes to being able to get the "right person for the job". It is a constant struggle to convince someone on the benefits to join your company when all your competitors are offering more or less the same bunch of benefits, career & growth opportunities. In so many years of my hiring experience, the most fulfilling moment is when a candidate accepts your offer & the next joyous moment is when he has joined as well.

Though a recruiter is always on tenterhooks, the most rewarding part of the job, are the words of gratitude that a recruiter receives when a candidate is informed about his selection. It is also a great feeling when a recruiter gets recognised by all their hires (though I must admit that I would not be able to recognise most of them!)

The other dimension of people interaction came when I moved roles & became a part of the Compensation & Benefits team. Sometimes I feel that handling your own employees is more challenging than an external candidate. That's because your employees have far more expectations from you and the organisation! You need a lot more patience to deal with them. Moreso when you are handling something as sensitive as someone's salary!

I have had friends, not in the HR fraternity, tell me that HR has it easy. That's so far from the truth! Managing aspirations, setting expectations, convincing employees that there is indeed a career for them in the company, handling miscreants who feel that they can flout a few rules in the company & get away with it, consoling an employee who feels injustice has been done to him/her, showing appreciation to an employee who has gone beyond the call of duty - all these are just some examples of the multiple roles that HR needs to play.

151121111.content:
I started working in many types of health care related jobs early on most of which were not glamorous. I didn't get a diploma. After several years learning the ropes from so many different types of jobs, nursing homes, retirement villa's, private sitting (with elderly), I felt that I could use with a change.
I applied for a job at a Center that had several Group Homes for the mentally and physically challenged adults in my area. It was a very hard job, most of the clients couldn't speak verbally and unless you worked with them a lot you wouldn't know that their eye's spoke volumes.
I began on the lowest level rung of the ladder and got the hardest jobs. Of course I did ask for them, I wanted to know if I was cut out to take care of such special people. Often becoming frustrated, not so much with the clients but myself. I did love the job very much.
One of my first days on the job I remember going into work worn out from the day before. I was signing in after I entered the room and one of the verbal clients came up to me telling me how their day went. Then it seemed like I was fitting in. We would take the company vans out and ride around. The clients liked being out in the community but really loved it when the chances arose for us to take drives in the country.
There was never a dull moment working with them. One client in particular loved to be nude anywhere, anytime, no warning just off came the clothes. There was even a time at our local park someone was having a child's birthday party and my clients started a major food fight with the birthday boy. All in fun no one was angry they just played and laughed.
One day you may go to work and receive a ton of hugs and then the next you may have to defend yourself from an agitated client. It was mostly great working with them. You come across a wide array of people in that field. Some who understand what its like to have a disabled family member, some I admit scoff and mock them. Which I was never good at handling, I had a temper when it came to my clients.
Strangers would often walk up to us on the street and tell me I must have been some kind of special to chose this job out of all the jobs. I would just tell them I don't feel special I just think it this way if this was my son or daughter I would want to know someone was taking care of them as well as I do.
Most of the staff are a great bunch of people, but in the health care business of mental retardation they aren't too trusting. I mean they are the advocates of the clients they care for. That's the same thing as you handing over your child to the first homeless guy you see and saying "Be back in a couple of days". It doesn't work out.
The hardest part of working in any health care setting I have found, is when you lose a client. Especially one you have been with a very long time. I still remember the first time I went to work and was told one of the clients had passed away. I wanted to cry but I couldn't the other clients wouldn't have understood. But when the day was over and I sat in my car I cried the whole way back home. The world felt a little more empty or at least my part of the world did. Eventually you grow a thick skin, it isn't impenetrable but it helps. It doesn't make you cold just human with a little protection added.
I have never forgotten one person I have taken care of. I miss them a lot and think of them often.
I think if your looking for a fulfilling job whose benefits often come in hugs or the joy you see on a persons face just because you came to work this is a good starting point.
Anyway this is my work story, truthful and direct. I hope you enjoyed reading this.

151121112.content:
My journey through life is one of romance, but not the sort that most would expect. When you're at sea for over half the year, you don't typically have time for long-term relationships. No. The sea is your wife, and your love. She is your mother and a killer. But no matter what, you know that she's beautiful.

When I was younger, I had no idea what I wanted to be. I'd lived in the wonderful state of Maine my entire life, a place where there truly aren't that many lucrative, high-octane jobs going around. We didn't have that many enormous businesses in my state. Certain department stores (one that starts with "W" and ends with "mart") have been severely detrimental to most of our ma and pop stores. Furthermore, I never could see myself as a full time worker - I'm a dreamer at heart. Being a lawyer or a doctor just wasn't for me; being a businessman is practically out of the question in Maine. But then there's the ocean.

The Atlantic's been within spitting distance of me my entire life; perhaps it's one of those things that I've taken for granted. She's a thing of majesty that cannot adequately be expressed by the words of even the world's greatest poet. There is no thought or word to define her, but you can feel her.

I'd never thought about shipping before my senior year of high school. I had always been anxious about my future. I found Maine Maritime Academy, and it changed my life forever. I'm not going to say that I'm a greedy man, or even that money is the most important asset in my life. What I will tell you is that I make a lot of it. I probably make more than your family physician does, and I also get nearly half the year off without any work obligations: free time to do whatever it is that I want. Please don't think that I'm bragging until you've read the rest of this.... chapter..?

A typical day in my life is that nothing is typical. I stand watch on the bridge of my ship every eight hours. Watch usually lasts for four hours unless the ship is getting ready for port, in which case the second mate and I have to cover the first mate's watch while he inspects the tanks. Weather can change nearly as fast as you can think. You quickly understand that nothing in the world is unpredictable. The sea can be still as glass one moment, and then minutes later, unleash aquatic hell. Even while docked, lines can part, people can be injured or killed, and malfunctions in any system could cause disaster for you or the environment.

To be asked what a typical day entails is to ask me the nature of the sea; to that I must say that each day, like the sea, is unpredictable.

When I'm on land, I have four months to do whatever I wish, with more money than most people would spend in four months (let alone a year or two... or three). But there is an enormous price. ENORMOUS. It's love. Looking back, I would rather have a career that would allow me to be with someone. My time away gives me no chance to establish the ties that are needed to fall truly, deeply in love. It really comes down to this: What is worth more to you: adventure and money, or a person who loves you? In retrospect, I'd choose love any day.

There are still many opportunities out there on the ocean. Many of them don't require you to be away for such a time. So it's not all bad. I, myself am thinking about transferring to a supply vessel in the gulf in order to get more time off (two weeks on the ocean, two weeks off). Perhaps then, I will be able to balance my career with my desires. Sailing is fun and adventurous while you are young, but when it comes time to find what really matters, you'll need to stop and reflect: what do you really want?

1511211121.content:
I work in the transportation industry. I have many bosses. As one of them recently said to me, "You take things too personally. We're not transporting Lungs and Hearts. If the load doesn't get delivered, it's not life-or-death."
But he's right. I DO take things personally. (Don't know about the word "too" though!) Everything is important. Even if it's just dog food or mulch to grow potatoes, it's important enough to be trucked somewhere. Right? I believe so.
By saying I have many bosses, I mean the following: I work in Maryland, for the Baltimore office, but I dispatch loads to drivers for the Norfolk, Virginia and Savannah, Georgia terminal managers. They are Mike and Chet, respectively. Mike is the one who said the silly thing about hearts and lungs. In most cases, I'm given a set of circumstances and need to fulfill them to finish my day. Quite often, I'm given a bit of warning. Other times, I'm given a surprise. I'll give you some examples.

Chet has a driver delivering in Florence, Kentucky this morning. Last Friday, I was able to find him a load that picked up only 7/10ths of a mile away (which is extremely rare). That's called a "deadhead", wherein the driver must go from his point of delivery to his point of pickup, without anything in his trailer. (Oh, I move VANS, which are the covered trailers most people see when they drive the highways. I do not move the flatbed trailers, where you can see what the load is, or at least see something is covered with a tarp.) After his deadhead, he picks up the load, in this case, in Florence, KY and is supposed to be delivering tomorrow in Manning, SC. But when he goes to pick it up, I get a call from the company who I booked it with, and they say, "We made a mistake. The load is really going to York, SC. Do you still want it?" So I have to negotiate a new rate to move the load to a different place. In this instance, I'm lucky the driver didn't have a load waiting for him in nearby Charleston, SC, which was the original reason I'd booked the load. Also luckily, the company who gave me the load (called a "broker") said they'd pay me the same amount of money to go a shorter distance, to give me some relief. Otherwise, I'd have to say NO to the load and find something else heading to Charleston, SC. In this case, I said YES and then started looking for something that would pickup near York, SC on Tuesday that would deliver in either Savannah or Charleston. I got lucky there too. I found a load within 50 miles that went directly to Savannah. That is also rare, in that I had no "deadhead" to home base.

Mike has a driver delivering in Humboldt, Tennessee this morning. I have a way to "post" the driver on a load board, so that other "broker" companies can find me and help me move him along. This driver has to return to Norfolk, Virginia, or within 100 miles of it, so he can take another load to Tennessee in a couple of days. The broker who calls me offers me a pickup that is 118 miles away in New Albany, Mississippi, that finishes in a town called Ahoskie, North Carolina, which is 65 miles deadhead back to home in Chesapeake, VA. The pay isn't quite what I need it to be, so I ask for more money. Eventually, the broker tells me they can meet my dollar figure and we "book the load". He sends me a piece of paper to sign and fax back to him. Then I send it down to my boss Mike, so he can let his driver know. Well, Mike actually had a pair of drivers in Humboldt today, so he got to choose which one would get this load.

I worked all day to find loads for all my drivers. But I still have one guy who will be in San Antonio, Texas on Tuesday, who really needs to get back to Savannah by the end of the week. There are several problems with this. One, the rate of pay from San Antonio is terrible in comparison to other pickup areas. The "ends of the country" don't pay as much as the middle parts. Seattle, Washington; Los Angeles, California; Boston, Massachusetts; Miami, Florida are examples of bad areas to ship from; mostly the brokers know that the drivers are desperate to get out of those areas, and therefore, do not pay a great amount of money to move the loads. Whereas I could get a rate of $2.00 per mile from Memphis, TN to Norfolk, VA; in San Antonio, TX, a load going to Atlanta, GA pays 85 cents per mile. Quite a difference!

I enjoy what I do, even though my wife and co-workers think I'm nuts. I do this every weekday and care for each and every one of the loads I book. I care for the drivers too. I love my job and am very good at it. New workers come in and say in extreme confidence, "You better not go on vacation. I can't possibly do what you do." But coworkers say, "You spend too much time on the phone. Get the person off the phone." They say that because I seem to be the only one people call for, day in and day out. But my theory is this: I'm talking to a potential customer and am not about to kick them to the curb because someone else is calling me. It's not my fault that three people called me at once. Other people could possibly help, but choose not to help. So all the calls are for me and usually one out of every six is a call I really didn't need to take anyway.

For example, I have a driver in Humboldt, TN that needs to go to Norfolk, VA. Every day! I got a call today from someone who wanted me to take their load to Brooklyn, NY. I mean, come ON, people! No matter how far away you get from the map, the miles between Brooklyn and Norfolk are the same. I can't really send my driver to a place that isn't within 100 miles of Norfolk, even if it does "pay well". So, if the coworkers would simply screen the calls, I wouldn't have to answer all of them all the time. But I'm not bitter. Most of the time! Okay, I AM bitter, but only at my clueless co-workers.

I've established a rapport with most of my customers (brokers) and they know me better because of that. I'd rather talk to a customer about innocuous things than kick them off the phone so I can do more of my job. The customer will give me the job, if I ask the right people. But if I simply tell them that others are waiting for me, it makes them think they are less important in my eyes. And that is never good to hear.

I've been working as a temporary services electrician for the Navy for the past seven months. I'm in an four-year long apprentinceship, but I practically do everything the senior electricians do already.

The hiring process for my position is very lengthy, because it is a federal job. You have to take a series of computer tests(having a degree or being a college student would definitely help you), and then you have do a physical fitness test(to see if you can climb in and out of a confined space), have a hearing, seeing, and physical done, and once you pass all of that, you finally get interviewed by a board of big-wigs, general foremans and supervisors who you'll be working for. You also have to have a clean record, because a federal background check will be run on you. Even having bad credit is nothing to sniff at if you want this job. The whole hiring process takes about four months.

If you're patient enough to go through the hiring process, the job is reletively easy once you get the hang of things. Since I'm an apprentice, I have to take a year and a half of technical classes, such as CAD(Computer Aided Drafting), Trignometry, and AC/DC electricity, in addition to my work schedule. It's nice the way it's set up, because with a two weeks at work/two weeks at college schedule, I don't have to worry about juggling work with school.

My job deals with providing temporary power to vessels who come into dock. Anything they need, like extra lighting, or extra power, I provide for them. It's a great position if you like variety, and you like working outdoors. Some days I'm outside providing power to a vessel, other days I'm inside my shop repairing circuit breakers, and other days, I'm walking around and making a report on repairs that need to be made to equipment. Plus I get to operate machinary like generators, booms, and cranes. It's a great job to have, considering by the time my apprenticeship is over I'll be making $20.50 an hour, which will only go up from there(I make $15.00 as an apprentice right now).

If you like working with your hands, troubleshooting, and working with ships, than this the job for you!

This is not entirely true but yes, I did love my job for a little while. The latest job I had to be precised. I've been working in the dining room on board the cruise ship since 2011. People usually get into some weird mood when I tell them what was my job because they can't wrap the thoughts around the idea of working on the ship, especially in my country where this isn't one of the common jobs and something you listen about on a daily basis. To be honest, I don't even know how did I finish working there. I only remember it was easy to get it because the interview for such position didn't require some crazy skills nor experience.
Ever since I was in primary school I dreamed about doing something unusual, something that not many people would or could do. Before I applied for this job I used to work in a bookstore. It was nice but the salary was low and I felt bored most of the time because there was no any action during the day. So, a friends and I were hanging out over at my place and the conversation we had turned toward careers and stuff. One friend of mine just suddenly mentioned job on the cruise ship because she knew someone from her college who got job there and before I even knew it I was holding a phone number of the agency that hires people for jobs on the ship. I called them the next day and made an appointment for the interview without even telling anyone. When I sorted everything out, when I sent documentation, I called my parents and told them about my plans. I'm not American which meant I had to travel and literally live in different country during my contract so it's, kind of, hard when you call your parents and tell them you're going abroad and that you won't see them for a whole year. Of course, they were okay with it and I was already old enough to make my own decisions. Only two months later I was already on my way to my very first job and new life adventures.

Ship's experience is hard to explain to someone who has never worked on one. Most of the people think about it as a great opportunity to travel the whole world and consider crew members lucky for it. While this job has its charms it also has its flaws. Yes, we indeed travel the world and see things that average human with ordinary job on land wouldn't see during his entire life but the crew members pay the high price for it by being away from everything and everyone they love- home and family. Length of the contracts depend on the cruise line you work for as well as department and your position. For example, officers on board usually have four months contract and two months vacation, waiters, stewards and just overall bar and restaurant department have eight months contracts and two months vacation. Some departments have six months contracts and two months of vacation.. like I said it depend on the job you are performing and cruise line company. It can happen that your position is unique on board and company has unique schedule for you. This happens with cruise directors, HR directors, captains, and few engine officer positions.

A day in life of a waiter on board is pretty busy. We used to make jokes saying how, to us, every day is Monday because at the ship no one has a full day off, like, ever. Everyone work every single day of their contract. One working day for a waiter usually starts at 7 am and finish around 10 pm with few short breaks in between. But it depend also of the schedule. Since the restaurant department is one of the biggest departments on board, shifts are split of course so it never happens that you work morning shift every day during one contract or even one cruise. In my company we had three positions for waiters: head waiter, team waiter, and assistant team waiter. One ship had two dining rooms and Lido deck (open buffet) so those three positions are split on each. For example, head waiters mostly had schedule to work breakfast (7-10 am), lunch (12-2 pm) and dinner in the dining room (6-10 pm) together with team waiters while assistant team waiters followed Lido deck schedule- breakfast 7-10 am, lunch 12-3 pm, and dinner they would work with head waiters and team waiters. Sometimes also Lido deck schedule had different working hours, especially when the ship is docked in a certain place or when we had midnight buffet therefore everyone had different schedule. Overall, there supposed to be around 10 working hours on days when you don't have off time and 5-6 working hours on days when you HAVE off time.

Being a crew member means changing your lifestyle completely. It's hard at the beginning because you need to adjust yourself to the working atmosphere, fact that you are going to work with people from all over the world who speak different language, have different habits etc. and also fact that you are going to be on the water 90% of time. But once you get on a roll it becomes easier of course. After some time you get used to ship life so much that you start to feel weird when being on land. Even walking on the steady ground may seem weird sometimes because at the ship you're always moving. I also had little bit of troubles when passing by strangers on the street. At the ship we all smile and greet even if we don't know each other, because we know we are still colleagues, living and working under the same roof. But smiling and greeting strangers on the street doesn't work that way. I mostly have to remind myself that I can't greet random strangers on the street for the reason I may look like crazy to them or something and because it's not natural, it is something that people just don't do.

Despite fact that average crew member work 10 hours per day, 8-6 months in a year, I can still say that it's possible to find enough of time for personal enjoyment. Crew members mostly enjoy even more than the guests in port because most of the time we know where to find the best fun on shore. For example, my first contract I spent in Mexico. We were basically every week in Cozumel and when you visit some place so many times you learn a lot about it and you never finish being on the same beach, or the same restaurant, mall etc. I literally know Cozumel like my own house because I explored 85% of the island. I've been to Australia, New Zealand, Alaska, Jamaica and many other countries I can't even remember. It is interesting to learn about different cultures, to visit historical sites, meet local people and have a conversation of some sort with them. This is something I dreamed about ever since I was in school. I always felt like I don't belong to just one place and that I need to look for something new all the time. Job on the cruise ship made my dreams come true and I realized that you can really have whatever you dream about if you are brave enough to pursuit it .

I am studying elementary education--and loving it!

I get to work in the elementary schools quite a bit, and I write lots of lesson plans. Which are fun, but a lot of hard work, especially if you're writing them for one of those professors who tells you everything that you need to include, even formatting. Preparing lessons is a lot easier when you're doing it for a real class and you don't have to turn it in.

Pros:
I get to work with innocent, curious children who enjoy learning--if learning isn't forced on them, and if they don't have teachers who try to make them into little adults.
I'm always meeting lots of friends, both children and fellow teachers, administrators, and parents.
I get to act like a kid! (although a very responsible one) I get to make things during class, teach songs and games, read, write, and play.
It is very fulfilling to teach someone something. So wonderful to see a light bulb go on over someone's head.

Cons:
To be able to teach, with the way public schools currently run, you have to be very organized, or you will not do well. If organization is difficult for you (as it is for me), you will have a lot of extra work to do.
Writing lesson plans is tricky. If you don't like planning (or don't like teaching what you've planned), being a teacher will be difficult.
While you are studying to become a certified teacher, you are bombarded with lots of different teaching styles, methods, etc. It is very confusing, with everybody telling you the "right" way to teach and constantly correcting you. If you don't want to make the same mistakes as are prominent in today's teaching, you have to have a lot of guts and plenty of determination.
Little pay, and way too much is expected of teachers. If there is not enough parental support, your students are in trouble, no matter how hard you try.
Teaching and classroom management are hard.

For me, most of the cons are due to governmental regulations or policies in the school district or other outside forces that take too much control over good teachers (and not enough control over poor teachers).

But for me, I wouldn't choose anything else as a job.

1511212.content:
There are many names for what I do, depending on what state or country you live in. I happened to do my training in Montana, which calls us CNAs. In Michigan, where I currently hang my hat, we are called CeNAs (pronounced seena). But whatever you call us, the job is the same.

You don't do this job for the money, because there is hardly any money in it. However, there are many other rewards that come with the job, not the least of which is personal satisfaction for having made someone's life better.

CNAs have a very difficult job. It's back-breaking, sweaty, muscle-pulling work. When you punch the time-clock and get on the floor, you'd better not have forgotten your deodorant that day, because no matter what the temperature is outdoors, you will break a sweat before you have your first resident out of bed. And most times, you have anywhere from 10 to 20 residents to take care of before 8 am, which is breakfast time at our facility.

We start day shift at 6 am, and have to get our residents up and dressed and into the dining room for breakfast. This entails everything from dressing the resident from the skin out, to giving showers to the ones that have them before breakfast. Time management is obviously very important in this job. After that is done, a couple of aides stay in the dining room to help serve the meal and assist in feeding residents.

There are usually 4 aides on a shift, so the other two are on the hall, serving the residents who stay in their rooms to eat. Then there is other work on the hall to do, like making beds, tidying rooms, checking oxygen concentrators, etc.

After breakfast, there are more showers to give, people to help get ready for doctor appointments, people to help ambulate, help get to activities, and miriad other things that we who are independant and not living in nursing facilities take for granted every day.

When we are done doing all that, it is time to get our people ready for lunch. This is not as time-consuming as the breakfast rush, because everyone is already dressed. Basically, we have to help people get to the toilet, comb their hair, wash their hands, and take them to the dining room. Then we help serve the meals and feed the people who can't feed themselves.

After lunch, we help people to the toilet again, take care of any showers we may have missed or people tried to refuse, and check oxygen concentrators again.

At the end of the shift, we have to chart what each of our charges did that day, and we have to do it as accurately as possible. This is very important because the information we provide is used to make care plans for the next month or 3 months, 6 months, etc.

When you're a CNA, you have an important job. You're helping people live and retain their identity, independance, dignity, and self-esteem. You always have to be professional, and remember that these are people you are taking care of, just as if you were caring for your parents or grandparents. It's a difficult, rewarding, challenging, and interesting job, and I love it. I am proud to be a CNA.

“Breadbaking is one of those almost hypnotic businesses, like a dance from some ancient ceremony. It leaves you filled with one of the world's sweetest smells...there is no chiropractic treatment, no Yoga exercise, no hour of meditation in a music-throbbing chapel that will leave you emptier of bad thoughts than this homely ceremony of making bread.” - M.K.F Fisher

It is approximately midnight. I am on my way to work. Most people my age are still out partying or asleep in their beds.

I'm twenty years old, and I work as a baker. Baking is a precise science, and it requires so much patience, love, and absolute feeling that very few people do it anymore. I am the last of a dying breed, I know, so I try that much harder to show people what they will be missing if the species dies out for good.

I switch on the lights and the ovens and toss the keys to the bakery on a hook in the office. It's not my office, but maybe someday. I pull a white apron down from the wall and secure it tightly around my waist. It's time. I weigh flour and water, fresh yeast and salt, sugar and sometimes even a little bit of dried fruit, butter or honey. All of the ingredients go into the mixer at the appropriate time until it looks and feels like I know it should. It is removed from the mixer bowl, and it is allowed to ferment. I do this for every dough on the rotation.

I am alone for two hours before the rest of my crew arrives. The bakery is very small so there are only two other people working in the kitchen with me. Gregory is in his early thirties. He used to work at some big corporate gig, but he hated it and we lucked out. Peter is young, just seventeen, and he still training so I have to watch over him at times. He gets frustrated easily when the dough does not work like he wants it to.

When the doughs are ready, they are divided, weighed, and shaped into loaves and rolls, all by hand. Then, they are allowed to proof. We bake other things too. We bake a few varities of muffins, cookies, and scones. We bake cakes for birthdays and weddings. Nothing is quite as sweet or rewarding as the breads though.

The retail portion of the bakery opens at 6:00 AM. The owner and his wife arrive earlier to brew coffee and set up the cash register. There is a line outside of the door before it is unlocked. By 8:00 or 9:00 AM, I will be heading back to my apartment, with flour clinging to everywhere. I'll take a shower. I'll have some breakfast. I'll call my mother back; she calls me everyday... and I'll go about the rest of my day wishing that I could still be baking bread.

I love what I do.

I am not famous. I simply work part-time at my local theater. My true calling is writing. But I LOVE to act, and so I do. <BR><BR>

The average day for me is getting up, having breakfast, and then driving to work. Once there, I do odd jobs, usually: hem a costume, help someone with their lines, paint a piece of the set, whatever. By nine, I'm in the "rehersal room" where I practice my lines for as long as I need to. After I get out, I head to the costume room and A) get fitted to my costume, B) tell my costume maker what needs to be fixed on my costume, or C) model my costume, sometimes practicing in it. Then I go and help with the sets, saying where they should go, etc. Then, my lunch break! I come back around 12:30 or 1:00, depending on the day. That's when the REAL rehearsing starts! The actors get together and the director has us run through the current show. He always stops us at whatever time and gives us feedback, or sometimes writes it down and hands us each a copy to practice with. Then we have time to give suggestions to everyone. Afterwards, I go to my private lesson, where I act out a scene from the show with the director. After a singing lesson and a choreographer date, I go home to write. <BR><BR>

Some days it's different. On the day after a show, we have time off. A few days after one, work will resume, and we'll get a new show. Auditions are held the next day.<BR><BR>

Other days, it's the SHOW DAY! That is really hectic. Goes like this: Upon getting to the theater, I meet up with every actor. We go through the show and really give suggestions. Then the director gives us a pep talk. We have group lessons, then go order lunch. After lunch, we change into our costumes in our respective changing rooms. After that, they do all the tech checks. Then we do a few scenes in costume, and finish lat-minute things fast. Our average time for the show is 6:00. We usually hang out there or go home to chill for awhile until showtime. Then everyone's running around and soon we hear someone announcing the show and regulations of the theater. And then we go!<BR><BR>

Acting is not as glorified as it sounds. It takes teamwork and cooperation. Everyone has to do well for the show to do well. And we don't get paid amazingly. 15112211212.content:
Working in the movies is not all glitz and glamour. There is a lot of hard work that goes on behind the scenes, especially when running a small, independent art cinema which is situated between two other cinemas owned by the biggest chains in the country! Yes, it is easy to feel marginalized and dwarfed! But despite all that, I endeavor to bring the very best, most interesting and worthwhile films to the screen so that audiences have an opportunity to see stuff that may not be so high profile.

Programming is a big part of my job, and is the most fun and the most frustrating part. There are a huge number of films released each week and distributors place them in appropriate cinemas. I have to convince the distributors that my cinema is the place they have to place the titles I want. In order to know what I want, I have to watch a lot of movies. Sounds great, but a lot of the time the films are not that good which makes it all the more wonderful when you see something that actually is! Maintaining excellent relationships with the film distributors is imperative. Getting films is highly competitive and sometimes it is your personal relationship that makes the difference between getting a title and not getting one!

We have three screens here which makes scheduling multiple titles possible. Each Monday I have to write a schedule for the week beginning Thursday, placing each film into a time-slot that will best suit that film's audience. Distributors usually have session demands as part of the contract for screening the film, so scheduling can get extremely tricky at times, especially if we have a festival or other event on. Once the times are locked in, everything else can begin.

Publicity is another huge part of the job. The films we screen are usually not blockbusters and do not get TV advertising, huge billboards or anything like that. Sometimes we don't even get a poster! Pre-release date I try to get the most exposure possible by direct-marketing to groups or organizations that may be interested in the film's subject matter. For example, today we are opening a film about marathon running so I have sent information to all the running and athletics clubs in the area and arranged for a specialist running shoe shop to put flyers in their bags. We also did a preview screening last night to which I invited all the marathon luminaries I could find- a surprising number!

A good relationship with the media is key. Our local paper only reviews 2 or maybe 3 films per week, and some weeks up to 9 films are released. So getting the reviewer in front of our film before his Wednesday afternoon deadline is important! Radio journalists who talk about films, street press reviewers and radio DJs are also important contacts to have. Upon finishing the schedule each week, I send it to all the media contacts I have so they know what is coming up that week, and can figure out how to see our films within their own deadline period. Luckily I am often suppled with "screener" DVDs that I can give to journalists so they can see the film, even if it is not screening at a time that suits them.

As well as all of this, there is the front-of-house work, serving customers, making coffee and supervising close-knit team as well as ordering and controlling the stock held in our bar and candy-bar area. Plus organizing and running events of all sizes and types. As our cinema has three different spaces, we are used for live music, theatre, conferences, weddings, parties and almost any other event you can think of.

It is a challenging job, especially as I am the only full-time employee. It often feels as though there are not enough hours in the day to get everything done. But I love what I do. I have a wonderful bunch of people to work with who are interesting, creative and talented. I get to watch a lot of fantastic films and I have the opportunity to use a wide range of my own talents and skills. Everyday is different, and everyday I get to meet new people. I take pride in my support of local film makers, and their work. I hope that my contribution is beneficial to New Zealand's small-but-growing film industry.

I work in an American aluminum-plant in Icelandic surroundings. And yes, I'm a native.

The process of making those foils in your kitchen-drawer is large and complicated, involving electric-conducting rods and some other techno-babble that I'm not familiar with. I'm just a small cog in a big clockwork, your basic labor worker.

Not all plants work the same way, but I can give you an insight into one of them. My place in the compound is the rod factory.

We basically receive used rods from a part of the plant where the aluminum is created (in so-called "tubs"), clean them, demolish and recycle. Transporting the rods through the factory is done by "forks", which hang from a suspended rail system that connects all the stations in the factory. If they are also damaged from the use in the aluminum-process, they're recycled too.

---


The job is actually rather exciting. Me and my fellow workers are on a cycle through the factory so you don't have to do the same thing on every 8-hour shift (thank God!). I will admit that I'm not in great physical shape so I perform sluggishly on some stations and better on others. If you intend on working in an industrial environment, you'd better have the endurance for it. Ladder-climbing and wielding sledge-hammers is not for a faint heart.

The great thing about this place though, are the co-workers. If your stuck on cleaning the forks in a certain stage and are completely exhausted (this is done by hand, I try to keep details to a minimum so not to confuse/bore you), you can always ask for help. I sometimes have to fight my ego, but it's always better to ask for assistance than to screw up big time. The reason for this is that there is rarely a deadline of sorts in this place, our main objective is to keep the stock of fresh rods up and then everything's a-okay.

The stations range from smelting the conduit-ore to the forks to transporting the ore and fresh/used rods. Everyone here has a favorite, I think. My personal favorite is anything that has to be done with the use of forklifts, trucks or other vehicles.

---


The best part about this job is the people you work with and get to know. There's nobody you can't talk or listen to. It may be a dirty and tiring work, but sometimes, one good joke with a colleague will make up for that. Oh, and the pay, there's always the pay.
