First I am not a midwife, yet. But I have worked as an apprentice for more than 4 years.

A typical "day" begins somewhere between the hours of midnight and six am. It begins like this. "Mamie? Holly called and she has been having contractions for three hours. They are now four to six minutes apart and getting stronger. She's having bloody show and can't talk through a contraction. I'll meet you at the birth center." I can tell that by this description that I need to leave ASAP. So I tell Amy, the midwife, that I am on my way and drag my sleepy body out of the bed. Quickly I pull on a set of scrubs and brush my hair back into a clip.

Henry rolls over and mumbles the question, "Got one cooking?"

"Yes," I reply while mentally determining what activities the kids have for the next 24 hours and who will be available to chauffeur them. I thank God that my parents are often readily available to fill in the gaps. "Dad will take care of the school route and getting (10-year old) Jamie to ball practice. Heather can fix "Hamburger Helper" for supper. What time do you get out of class"? Now what day is it? I wonder. "Do you work tomorrow"? I ask.

My husband is a paramedic and full-time college student. Between classes and swapping shifts with co-workers, I don't even try to keep up with all the schedule changes. I just ask.


"I get out at 9:30, and yes, tomorrow is Saturday. I work. I'll ask your dad to get Jamie to her game." I love this man! I plant a quick kiss on his forehead and rush out the door as he calls for me to be careful and call him when I get there.


The birth center is two hours of mostly state highways and farm to market roads away. Traffic is minimal; but since I pass over two lakes and a few roadside ponds, fog is often present.


I crank up the radio to the local contemporary Christian station and sing along. I am somewhat anal about not breaking the rules, or at least about not wanting to get caught breaking the rules. So while the speed limit in most areas is 70/65 at night, I set the cruise on 70 to 73 and hope to squeak past any troopers.


Keeping an eye out for an open gas station since I once again didn't fill the van, I flick the lights on bright to watch for deer. Of course, if the furry four-legged creatures would read the signs and only cross at the posted crossing, I wouln't have to worry about blinding the on-coming traffic when I inevitably forget to dim the lights.


An hour and a half later, I pull into the station for a quick fill up and a French vanilla cappuccino. That done; I am back on the road.


Now, I realize that the machine manufacturers probably think if they made cappuccino at the temp where you could actually drink it, then it would probably cool too quickly. But, I am of the opinion that if it was at a drinking temp, then I would be able to drink it quickly and might have to purchase more. Oooh, profit!


As I pull up to the birth center, I accomplish four things almost simultaneously. First, I finish my cappuccino. Then I pop a stick of bubble gum flavored gum into my mouth to cover the coffee smell and any remaining "morning breath." Yeah, my priorities are out of order; I'll take the time for a cappuccino, but not for brushing my teeth. "Extra!" to the rescue (of my clients.) Next, I make that call to my husband, and finally, switch the phone to silent.


Stepping into the birth room, I survey the situation. Birth supplies ready? Mom, how close does she appear to be to delivery? Answers? Mom is not pushing. She and Amy are visiting between contractions. Whew! I can slow down and take a breath.


Birth supplies are purchased by the client and in this case they are already out and ready for use. I glance around the room. Towels are warming on the heating pad? Crock pot is simmering the herbal tea with wash clothes to be used for warm compresses during pushing? Mom has something to drink? Dad is fulfilling the role of support person?


I pick up the chart to see where we are at, when the next set of vitals are needed, if the mom has any conditions that I need to remind myself of, and if the parents have any special requests for their birth.


That accomplished. It is time to listen to the baby. Baby is active as every movement sounds like a kick to the doppler speaker. Fetal heart tones are supposed to be between 120 and 160 beats per minute. They are, and I chart them, noting the time they were checked.


Out of hospital birth has a whole perspective and set of terms that are different from a hospital planned birth. For instance, we SERVE; we serve CLIENTS; and we CATCH babies. Midwives offer a service. Our clients are our customers. Customers are informed and asked to participate in decision making. We see the mother as delivering the baby since she does the most work and we "catch" the baby. We are trained in preventative care and to recognize normal variations of pregnancy, labor, birth, newborn, and postpartum care.


Doctors are AUTHORITY figures for which most people have been conditioned to obey without question. Doctors have PATIENTS. Most doctors see themselves as DELIVERING the baby. Doctors are trained to look for problems and a lot of their ob rotation is spent in surgery. I am glad that they know how to do surgery as there are times when it is certainly necessary!


You get the idea. So I will jump down off my soapbox and back into the birth.


Hours pass, while we give supportive care to both the mother and other family members that may be present. We offer choices of activity and changes of position that may help the baby into a better position for delivery.


Mothers have the option to labor and/or deliver in water or on "land." Water offers pain relief even while sometimes increasing the strength and effectiveness of contractions.


For a land birth, we place several chux pads beneath the mother. Further, mothers are offered many positions for delivery. Mom can recline against her spouse or pillows. She can lie on her side with her top foot resting against the midwife's shoulder. Dad can sit on the side of the bed and use his legs to provide an open seat for Mom, or he can use his strength to hold her upright while she squats into the contraction.


Mom can stand with one foot on the bed and one on the floor while Dad stands close by offering support and the midwife sits on the floor ready to catch. This position is often alternated to encourage a baby to turn its head to tuck and align itself better. A well tucked and aligned head presents the smallest diameter for pushing through a pelvis.


Many times a mom will use more than one of these options during a delivery. First time moms especially change positions more frequently. It is just that until you've pushed before (without medication), you don't really know how to do it. So changing the position helps keep the baby moving down and out. Of course if baby is having no trouble moving down the pelvis, we leave well enough alone.


Birth accomplished. It's time to facilitate family bonding. We do this by encouraging the mother to breastfeed the baby. We also offer an herbal bath to mom and baby. Once latch on is obtained and mom and baby are comfortable. We leave the room to allow for privacy and bonding.


For two hours, we return every 15 to 30 minutes to assess both mom and baby and quickly leave if everything is normal. Sometime during the first and second hour, we return to perform a complete newborn exam and give mom postpartum instructions.


Once mom has eaten, been up to use the restroom and bathe, both mom and baby's vital signs are withing normal limits, and at least two hours have passed, we can release them to go home.


When the family leaves, it is time for clean up. We strip the bed and get the laundry started. We disinfect and clean up any spills, remake the bed, and take out the trash. After a final look over our charts, a birth summary is completed. Everything ready for the next birth; we can go home PROVIDED that it is not an appointment day.


Lots of midwives set aside one or two days a week for appointments. These are frequently scheduled full of appointments every half hour. Word to the wise, don't schedule a high-maintence client before lunch or quitting time, or you will never get away.

Appointment days have can have prenatals, postpartums, and if you have an ultrasound machine - ultrasounds.

A typical prenatal goes like this. "Amanda, hi, have you left us a sample"? If she replies, "Yes," then I reply, "Ok, let me check that and then I will weigh you." That done; we go into the prenatal room.

While observing Amanda and anyone accompanying her, I begin her physical assessment. I look for clues as to her physical and emotional well-being. I take her blood pressure, check the position of the baby, listen to fetal heart tones, and measure her fundal height.

"Amanda, is the baby moving"? I inquire.
"Yes."
"And do you have any swelling"?
"No," she replies.
"Your urine was clear, and your blood pressure is 106 over 74," I say. "The baby's back is on your left side which is a good position for to start labor. The heart rate was 136."
"Do you have any questions or concerns"? I give her opportunity to express them and discuss options available to her for comfort measures.

Addressing the mom's concerns with practical advice and encouragement is a big part of an appointment. Handouts are often given to reinforce education given during a prenatal or postpartum visit.

"Everything looks good from our stand point. If something comes up that you have a question about, just give us a call or email." I end the appointment with this statement so that my client knows that I am concerned about her and available to her for supportive care.

Postpartum check ups involve both the mom and baby. Both are assessed. Mom for her healing after the birth. Baby for growth and development. State required testing is completed. Everything is charted. Finally we visit and continue our care with education and encouragement.

That concludes the standard care aspect of midwifery. Outside of this, there can be advertising of services, continuing education of the midwife, training of personnel and apprentices, advocating with the public for the rights of birth choices and breastfeeding, reviewing of charts, devising ways to improve services, teaching nutrition childbirth classes, offering to doula hospital clients, consulting on breastfeeding issues, bookkeeping income for tax purposes, filing insurance claims, and fighting lawmakers and physician for the right to offer choice of care to families concerning birth.

I'm actually a university student with various little jobs here and there. But the one I want to try and do something with is restoring fountain pens.

You know what a fountain pen is, right? Those things with the shiny metal bits poking out the ends which nobody uses anymore? They were the most common writing-instrument before the late 1940s and 50s when the ballpoint pen came on the scene and the world of pens let out a collective sigh and groan at the same time.

Vintage fountain pens, anywhere from 25, 50, 75, 80, 90, 100 (and over) years old - are highly collectible and various models are especially sought-after. The Waterman '52' from the 1910s, the Parker Duofold from the 1920s, the Parker Vacumatic from the 1930s, the Parker '51' from the 1940s and 50s and so on and so forth.

Most collectors of fountain pens (of which I am one) prefer collecting and buying pens that actually...WORK. After all, if you collected radios or vintage cars or antique clocks, you'd want them to work, too, right?

That's where I come in (or I will, in a few years' time).

Competent fountain-pen restorers are few and far between. It's truly a niche-market. In the "old days", any company gladly repaired a fountain pen, either for free, or for a price. Unfortunately, such pen companies do not repair pens (even though they were MADE by that very company), if they are beyond a certain age.

Restoring a vintage fountain pen to working condition is both challenging and fun, easy and hard, relaxing and frustrating. Fountain pens are much like motor-cars - they have to run smoothly, they have to have a working fuel-delivery system and they must have an operational filling system and fuel-containment area.

The "wheels" of a fountain pen is the nib. The nib must be smooth, level and free of kinks. It must have plenty of tipping-metal as well, to prevent wearing down of the nib-metal (think of tipping-metal as if they were car-tire threads. They perform the same function, more-or-less).

The fuel-delivery system is the feed, a long plastic (or rubber) thing-a-ma-jig that transports ink from the fuel-tank - the ink-sac, to the nib. The feed is made up of little channels and gills and these must be cleaned and scrubbed so that old ink and other sediments may be removed. This is so that the ink will flow smoothly.

The next major part is repairing the filling-system. This can include replacing rubber ink-sacs, fixing filling-mechanisms such as buttons, levers, slides, pistons, knobs...see? A fountain pen really can sound like a machine.

That's all the inner workings of the pen. Then comes repairing the 'bodywork' - that is - fixing clips, cap-bands, chips, dings, scrapes, cracks, cuts, engravings, brassing, rust - etc. A properly restored fountain pen should work for at least as long as it was previously designed to last for. And considering that some are nearly 100 (and some over 100) years old and still working - means that these things were built to last.

I've only just started on restoring fountain pens and my current project is a Waterman lever-filler from the 1940s. Yeah that's right, folks. Let's take a trip back to World War Two! By the time I'm done with this darling, it'll be running just as good as it did when it was first-used. It's fun and challenging, but the end result is worth it.

We start each class on the dot - seriously. We wait until the clock ticks over onto the hour.

Classes are exactly 55 minutes, and we have exactly 5 minutes in between classes to get a drink or go to the washroom.

If it's a long day (6 classes) we get an hour lung in between.

Our style of school is based on self study. Student learn from a computer lesson then come to our class for the review - which is pretty much a "test" class to see if they understood and can move on to the next lesson. We never actually teach - we elicit the answer from the student.

By the end of a long day, I'm pretty mentally exhausted

The good parts about my job

I have total creative freedom over my "open classes" and have done some pretty fun stuff. Including setting alcohol on fire.

Difficult students - our school is "self study" based, if they have trouble in class, rather than taking responsibility for their lack of preparation (and general laziness) they scream at us that it's our fault they didn't learn anything.
I'm living in a communist country that is riddled with red tape, which makes the job hard sometimes.

A DAY IN THE LIFE OF A FUND DEVELOPMENT OFFICER

I was the first college graduate in all the generations of my families who came from Europe three and five generations earlier. It was a proud moment for me the first day I attended classes in college September of 1956 after graduating from Modesto High School.

College graduation at Fresno State College that June 1960 was a beautiful Sunday afternoon and I proudly accepted my Bachelor's Degree which prepared me for teaching English, Writing, History and Social Studies. Those were my favorite high school courses so I thought it would be great to teach those subjects to high school and junior high students.

The contract I signed with Ceres, California School District said that all of my classes but one would be eighth grade Creative Writing and one seventh grade math class. I developed the curriculum for Creative Writing and during the year and my students produced some wonderful poems and essays. I loved teaching the classes and watching the least capable among them become creative writers. I still have some of their writings which I read again recently. To this day, I think the District should never have employed a math teacher who had not studied how to teach math. While I did my best to teach my math students, I have always thought they were cheated by the District for requiring a non-math teacher to hold them hostage an hour a day. The students deserved a teacher trained in the art of teaching math, not a teacher who knew her math very well but had no training in teaching it.

After teaching for several years, I changed vocations and became the Volunteer Director at the Idaho State School and Hospital for the intellectually disabled. That was 1969 and I quickly fell in love with the accomplishments that I could cause by doing the statewide job I had accepted. One goal was to teach people all over the state to stop using words like 'idiot, imbecile, moron, mongoloid and worse' names. At that time, the words 'mentally retarded' was the most respectable term we wanted people to use. At the same time, the job included recruiting and training ordinary people and students of all ages to visit the institutional home of over four hundred individuals and make personal contributions to their lives. It didn't take long for me to fall in love with that job and the wonderful volunteers who gave of themselves to help individuals who just wanted a friend. I worked with women who were community leaders to raise funds and build the All Faiths Chapel at the institution which today, years later, serves less than two hundred residents and patients, most of whom can't understand religion; but, I believe they know God.

Those experiences and others led me to accept the position of Development Director, a fund raiser, to raise money for hospitals and other nonprofit activities. My years of fund development led to raising over six million dollars for my organizations. I developed the Fund Development Program at Mercy Medical Center, Nampa, Idaho, by making speeches to all community groups in the area while designing and implementing a Direct Mail program for sending those 'infernal' letters asking for donations that every resident in America receives from charitable organizations. It takes a heart and skill to write those letters in a way that leads thousands of people to write checks and give their money for the benefit of someone else.

Development Directors like me, learn how to plan and implement fund raising events and activities that are so much fun that people give money to the charity. The primary part of such events was the recruitment of community leaders and other talented and interested people to serve on the planning committee. For the Annual Tennis Tournament which lasted more than ten years, I recruited five tennis players who served as the planning committee all of those years. Restaurant Manager

I am not sure that I planned to be a restaurant manager for a corporation any more than any small child wakes up one day and says, “I want to be a car salesman!” It just happened. Becoming a chef… now that’s a great idea, and one that I can see a person wanting to pursue. Becoming a restaurant manager in the family dining sector, however… well, you may want to hear a little bit about what it’s like.

Don’t get me wrong. This is the absolute best job I can ever think of for myself, and I wouldn’t trade it for the world. But it’s not for the faint at heart, for sure. I oftentimes laugh at guests who look at us as if we work in the restaurant industry because we were not qualified enough to work in any other vocation. We don’t do it for the money, I admit. We do it for the challenge. We are adrenaline junkies who have found a mainstream job to make us feel right. My job is to ensure complete guest satisfaction and feed a family of five everything from pancakes to a steak dinner within eight minutes, ensure that all of the food ordered comes off the grill at the exact same instant, timed in a way that the server can get it out to the table as soon as it hits the heat lamp at the same time as I am tending to a guest who is waiting to pay, three more who need to be seated, and repairing a walk-in cooler that does not want to keep temperature. Now, multiply that by 50 guests an hour for 12-14 hours and 6 more equipment breakdowns. Here’s my… “A Day in the Life…”

There is no typical day. Of course, you walk into every day with a plan, which you often throw out the window before most normal people have had their first full cup of coffee. At 4 a.m., I am ready to go, having had half a pot of coffee already, I drive to work with a plan, an agenda of things to accomplish that day. There are community fundraisers begging for my attention, and more than my share of administrative duties to perform. I have food orders to place for everything from fresh produce to ice cream to steaks and eggs. Throw into that mix the incredible span of personalities employed by me: combine with love. Now, Sally is always fighting with her boyfriend and needs to be talked down by someone before she is expected to be “on” (the term we use for being in the public… we are always on stage). Bart is usually late and works three jobs just to make ends meet. Jerry is sick a lot, but there are rumors that it has to do with extra-curricular activities rather than his health. Easily, one would say these folks should be let go. However, good employees in this industry with only a fault or two are hard to come by. You set up the roster with what you’ve got and you fight the good fight, day in and day out.

It’s 11 o’clock. Lunch hour is open me before I realize it. My second cook has not come in to help cover the lunch hour. He lives with his Mom, so I call her. She assures me he left for work at the same time he always does (I find out later she hasn’t seen him since the weekend before). As I’m on the phone, my cook comes to tell me that he can only keep one fryer lit. Going into lunch on a Fish-Fry Friday… this is the worst time for this to happen. Then again, Murphy’s Law is not one for timing. At the same time that I am working to light the fryer, the dishwasher tells me no one has pulled the fish from the freezer for the special.

A customer has a complaint about bad service from a server. I go to the dining room to find out if there’s anything I can do to rectify the situation. Winds up it’s a good friend of mine. I offer her a free meal the next time she comes in for the inconvenience of not getting her milk with her meal. She agrees and leaves happy.

The driver for the produce company comes in with the order only to tell me that they ran low things and were not able to complete my order. I quickly call the local grocery store and ask for the produce manager. When he finds out who I am, he cuts me a wholesale-type deal on the purchase and I send an employee to pick up what we need.

The char broiler catches on fire during lunch and I put it out, instructing the cook to replace all of the burnt items he tried to make on the char broiler on the flat grill until I can get the mess cleaned up. Praise salt and all of its powers in putting out fires.

Shortly after lunch, the dish machine springs a leak. We’re washing dishes by hand. Not that much slower, but air drying is not the quickest. Thankfully, lunch is coming to an end.

Second shift is ready to start. A server calls in. A big snow storm is coming. Tourists are flocking in for snowmobiling. The lights go out in the dining room….

This is a day in my life, and I love it! Sorry if some of you have to sit in an office all day. I could never do it!

I am one of those people for whom the life chosen did not seem to want to choose me back. It's not that the life I had wanted for myself was overglamorized--no one could believe what I wanted to do was glamorous--but, rather, that it had been reduced to a series of formulas to memorize and backs to stab.

My dream, for those who don't know me, has always been to be a professor of American History. I'm one of those people who feel that the study of history is paramount to our understanding of the present and, even, the future. Humans are predictable creatures as a species and, as such, we continue to make the same decisions, whether for good or ill. I wanted to tell people the story of our existence--or, at least, the portion of that existence in which America has taken part--and I wanted to make people love history as much as I do.

Unfortunately, the people who control the purse strings seem to believe that math and science are more important than the humanities and social sciences. As such, within the world of academia, for every one job there must be at least eighty applicants. And cronyism, though most of us know the consequences of that particular sin in our nation's history, continues to run rampant within our world. But I wasn't worried; not really. I was good. I am good at what I do. In a world not known for its...entertaining writing style, I had all the benefits of being a creative writer and a world full of editors here at W.com (for which I thank everyone). My writing had caught the attention of pretty much every professor I'd ever had and, especially, my Civil War professor. So I could have done it.

Then came the hell that is graduate school. I was still a big fish (amongst other big fish, admittedly, but I still had the backing of my adviser), but something had changed. Suddenly, my creative writing skills became a hindrance instead of my calling card because that "wasn't how historians wrote". All of my passions, my courses of study until then (mostly the power of public memory in creating history, especially when the public memory is, in fact, false), were deemed to be too "loaded" and not "disinterested". My habits of looking at history from the perspective of a political scientist (my minor) or a philosopher (my not-quite-second-major), or ESPECIALLY an anthropologist (apparently it's OK to be ethnocentric in History) became habits that I needed to rid myself of.

Essentially, my passion and my differences alienated me from my chosen field. I couldn't quote every book I'd ever read, either, even though I was encouraged to practically skim each book I was assigned. Literally, it became about parsing details and rote memorization, which were the parts of history I'd HATED in high school. Mostly, it was attempting to make me into something I wasn't simply because what I was was apparently NOT a historian. I went into the humanities to avoid that very sense of narrowness, but apparently it exists everywhere.

I think I realized I didn't want to do it anymore when someone in my class said: "I am a historian, not a writer" and the professor agreed with him. When it became apparent that historians study history in order to promote themselves amongst themselves, I decided that I couldn't do it anymore. I wanted to be a historian in order to teach people to love it, to share something that I dearly loved, and came to realize that that's not what historians do.

So now I'm a former historian-in-training. Unfortunately, things don't always work out the way you planned. So I've changed my dream to reflect what I'm good at: writing. Luckily, I've got y'all to help me out.

Unfortunately, not every large format print shop provides a good working environment. So be selective if you can. Before I worked at Job2, I worked in an even smaller shop I’ll call Job1. So, if I could give a green designer a pointer or two: Be selective about where you start out because more than likely if you’re anything like me, you’ll end up in that kind of design environment over and over. Secondly, learn all you can from the instructors at school. Use the lab computers and software as much as possible, look up tutorials and do them en-masse, and reach for the stars.

Making films meant I was able to indulge in my passion, traveling. Sri Lanka, Thailand, Jamaica, Turkey and the United States; I lived some unbelievable experiences in those countries that deserve to be ink on paper. I was lucky to say the least. I was consistently given grants, either from my university or media companies, to make films that I personally did not think were that great. To be honest, I didn't like filming that much. I was never a huge film fan, I hate the practical aspect of the job, such as camera settings and where to place the lighting and the rest of the technical mumbo-jumbo. I just wanted to travel, to experience things and live my life so that I have something to write about.

On top of that I am quite introverted and the camera was a great thing to hide behind. I felt more brave, I felt protected by that clunky machine and it helped me slowly grow into a curiously aggressive woman. I saw war and poverty ravaging the people I felt deserved it the least. I discovered that the people who have the least give the most. I understood the innocence and naivety of children to everything surrounding them, and that whether you're in an upscale neighborhood in London or the slums in India, children play, fight and laugh the same. I also experienced the other end of the spectrum: I saw how people use others when they sense weakness, as if we were in a jungle, not conscious, cognizant human beings. My lens helped me grow the courage to stand up for others and for myself. Anyone I captured with my camera lens became part of my life.

After all my travels, which didn't get me much in terms of film, I went back home and worked as a production assistant for short films. I would scout for locations, edit scripts, buy props, obtain the proper filming licenses, arrange catering for shoots, cast actors, schedule filming days, budget, etc. Not all of it was fun, but I did get to drive around the country a lot with my production manager. He was a large man, and I was intimidated by him from day one, even though a smile never left his face. During my first days on the job he payed a lot of attention to me, guiding me a lot and pushing me to be more curious about all aspects of the job. We quickly became friends. We laughed at the bad actors together, complained about the tyrannical directors, fussed about the budget and our shopping trips for film props quickly turned into lunch dates and dinner dates. Today we are engaged to be married.

My experience as a Film Producer Assistant is probably different than one who is passionate about his job. For me, like many of you, I just want to write. Whether I am good at it or not, it's the only thing that feels natural to me, and I feel confident doing it. This job was just a gateway to writing material, and I know no other way of expressing myself.

1512212212.content:
Fritter away my life... sometimes it feels like it as I sit in front of the computer, reading another bland email or filling out another pointless personality test but the truth is, I am very accomplished. Those time killers only occupy a truly small fraction of my life.

         Sure, there are some who look upon my career and turn up their noses. The pay's lousy, there aren't any technical benefits and I'm sure as heck not getting insurance but I am changing the future of our world as we know it with every action that I make.

         Yeah, that's right, I'm an at home mother. Once upon a time, this seemed like an easy job. Sit around, play on the computer, watch this cute kid and I was good. I look back at those days as blissful naivete. Nothing in life is quite so simple, especially not when you're a mother of not one but three girls.

         Every day, I find myself taking on a plethora of careers that just weren't in the job description. Have you ever tried being a bouncer to three unhappy dramatic girls while recovering from surgery? Exhausting, especially when you consider I must also be chef, duck wrangler, maid, dry clean operator, coach and so many more little jobs.

         But I can't begin to tell you how rewarding it is. Seeing my daughters grow into these young girls who are strong and proud of who they are. They are kind spirited and compassionate, warm and filled with a sense of humor. The world is their oyster and I know that I am doing the best that I can because I am seeing the best in them. Makes my heart hurt and want to burst out of my chest but in the best possible way.

         Of course, I also write and I sell my artwork online and at local boutiques. That's fun too but all of it pales in the accomplishments I achieve as a mom. Mushy, perhaps but every word is true and I wouldn't trade a moment of it.

I have worked in a number of places and was taught an awful lot, but the one thing that has taught me the most is being a housewife/mom. Your job is never done and you have the ability to help shape your children into great young men and women of tomorrow. I take my job seriously and I love it with my whole heart.

Who is in a better place that than you are by being involved with them in every aspect of their lives. We take for granted the ability that we have to shape the next generation. We can help to create astronauts, presidents, lawyers, other stay at home parents and spouses, or any other title you can throw out there. We help to shape them, mold them, create in them the person they choose to be in this life. We should be called miracle workers for the most part.

My kids are not astronauts, presidents, or lawyers, but they are good citizens of our country. They are great young men and my husband is a faithful and giving man. They can be born who they want to be, but most of the time it takes us slowly coaxing them over time to be that "somebody" they want to be.

We change the world a child at a time.

151221221221.content:
I have battled career choices since high school and I never did go to college. I wanted a year off to just work and experience the work voice. I started with waitressing for a couple of years and I really liked it. My best experience was fine dining. I loved lighting the candles and making salads in front of couples from scratch. Our specialty drinks were also made at the table. We had carts to flambé bourbon , and speciality coffees. It was always a treat to hear about the reason for the special dinner. Anniversary stories, birthdays, a new expecting mother, and the list goes on. I have heard so many wonderful stories.

From that I went to Hostess of a Hotel Company in the west. Although I thought I would like it, I found it too behind the scenes. I enjoy being with the people more. So I sent a resume to Lake Louise to work in a resort. I got the job but I chickened out and didn't want to leave home.

After that I entertained the thought of Retail. I started as a stock girl in a shoe store and over a course of two years I became manager. I managed the store for two years and was approached to be trained in Merchandising in head office. I was so excited I couldn't tell you how much. My problem was I had my son that year and I became ill shortly after, then my son became ill and I never did go back to work.

Being a mother and caregiver is a full time job. It is hard and stressful and tiring, but the rewards are in the heart and that counts for so much.
Although I would never give up my now new calling in life, my other choice would be merchandising. I love putting things together and my motto has always been, "It isn't about the product but it is all about the presentation."
I say that also for gifts. "It doesn't matter about what is in the box but how you present it.'
I tend to go over board with deco's on the gifts and I always write a special note for each one.

1512212212211.content:
At the age of 22 I was in college working on a 4 year degree, I had already completed a 2 year Associates Degree in Business Administration. We were shocked with the news, my girlfriend was pregnant. We were young, unmarried and both still going to school. We chose to marry, have the child and she would continue with school. When my wife completed school, she'd then work and I'd finish my bachelor's degree. At this time I was working two jobs, one as a storeroom clerk and weekends as warehouse stocker/order filler.

As life often does, I got spun in circles, after completing school my wife decided to file for divorce. So much for her working while I finished school. Now it was paying child support, living with a friend and working two jobs. Fortunately the warehouse job turned into a full time receiving clerk position with benefits. This then turned into a department manager's job in sporting goods. I stayed in retail management for 3 years then took an 8 to 5 Monday to Friday sales position in Restaurant/hotel equipment, which lasted for 5 years. The sales experience lead to another sales position in the technology sector; selling design software & services to Architects, Engineer's and General Contractor's.

Now my current position, each day begins with an hour commute to our downtown office. Arriving at my desk first up is reviewing current quotes, upcoming software maintenance renewals and top prospects. Top prospects are reviewed in a web portal; current construction projects, who are their design partners, and key staff leading these projects. Once I know who they are, who they work with and what they are working on now comes the internal meetings with technical staff; how to we leverage our software/services portfolio to create a compelling presentation. Calls/emails are sent to arrange meetings. At a team we'll hammer out which features in the design software we'll cover and what services to recommend.

Once the days scheduled calls and meetings are completed I'll pull up the recommended training and professional development. Which ranges from web classes on new benefits included with software maintenance to how to create a business process audit.

Each day is similar, schedule meetings, visit customers, create or follow up on quotes. There are two other business providing the same products/services, it is very competitive with shrinking margins. As a sales role there is tremendous pressure to keep customers, close business and find new business.

Considering not finishing my 4 year degree I feel fortunate. There is the pressure, reparative nature of the job and fluctuating income so what are the other options?

info.brief_description: Learn about different occupations and tell us about your own!
info.description:
All of us come to that point in life where we are asked, "so, what do you want to do with your life?"

The Senior Year in High School comes and we are faced with scholorship opportunities, college choices, and the often dreaded question, "So what are you planning on studying?"

Looking at college courses doesn't give anyone a true idea of the profession and the daily activities it involves. TV is often warped, not giving off a true perception, and covers so few occupations.

Many times, careers aren't all they are stacked up to be...perhaps they are over glamorized. And there are many careers that are hardly noticed, but have great rewards.

Hopefully we'll uncover a wide range of career paths in this interactive.

Write about a day in the life of your occupation...whether it be a Homemaker, a Lawyer, a Janitor or and Engineer...whatever your path is, write about it and let us in on the true aspects of the job.

If you have an additional story or experience to tell, use the choices at the bottom to "read more about..." or "choose another profession." Always give an option to choose another profession.

One more thing - title your chapter the occupation or the job title you are in.
